Coinye

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

This article needs to be updated. Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information. (December 2022)
Coinye


Inflation	Limited release, production rate before this limit re-evaluated with the production of every block (at a rate of approximately 1 block per 90 seconds) based on the difficulty with which COINYEs are produced, eventually leading up to a final total of 133,333,333,333 coins.
 Method	1 reward is released per block found. Rewards halve every 100K blocks.
Coinye, formerly Coinye West, is[1] a scrypt-based cryptocurrency. Cease and desist letters were issued against it for its use of the American hip hop artist Kanye West, as its mascot despite West having no affiliation with the project.[2][3] The project was abandoned by the original developers following West's filing of a trademark infringement lawsuit against them.

[4]

History
Release
Coinye was originally slated for release on January 11, 2014, but legal pressure prompted David P. McEnery Jr. and his development team to release the source code and mining software on January 7, a few days ahead of schedule.[5] Early press materials promised a proper and fair release, with no pre-allocation of coins.[6] However, later statements from the developers confirmed that approximately 0.37% of the maximum money supply of Coinye had been reserved for the creators of the coin before launch.[7] The developers claimed that this was to cover unexpected legal and development costs.

Trademark-infringement lawsuit
On January 6, 2014, Kanye West's lawyers sent the development team a cease and desist order on the basis that the then-unreleased currency constituted trademark infringement, unfair competition, cyberpiracy and dilution.[8][9] In response to the legal threats, the development team changed the name of the currency from "Coinye West" to "Coinye" and moved to a new domain name.

[10] By January 10, 2014, the development team stated that they had removed all references to West but instead "to a half-man-half-fish hybrid," a nod to a South Park episode in which West fails to realize why people are jokingly calling him a "gay fish."[11] These actions were not sufficient to appease West's legal team, and a lawsuit was filed against the creators of the coin, prompting them to sell their Coinye holdings and leave the project.[12]

Developer departure and community takeover
On January 14, 2014, a representative of Coinye announced on Reddit that "the developers basically dumped all their coins on the one exchange and left the scene."[12] Coinye's official site was replaced with text reading "Coinye is dead. You win, Kanye." and the original website is now down.[13]

Decline (2014-2020)
Coinye has been called "defunct" by numerous publications.

[14][15][16] Coinye's global block difficulty fell from 78 to 1.012 between January 18, 2014,[17] and May 7, 2014,[18] indicating that the network's total processing power fell by roughly 99% during that time. According to music writer Sasha Geffen, in the midst of the 2017 cryptocurrency bull market, Coinye would have risen in value up to twentyfold, had Kanye West not threatened legal action.[19] However, in 2017, few people were still trading or mining Coinye.[20]

Litecoin (Abbreviation: LTC; sign: Ł) is a decentralized peer-to-peer cryptocurrency and open-source software project released under the MIT/X11 license. Inspired by Bitcoin, Litecoin was among the earliest altcoins, starting in October 2011.[3][4] In technical details, the Litecoin main chain shares a slightly modified Bitcoin codebase. The practical effects of those codebase differences are lower transaction fees,[5] faster transaction confirmations,[4] and faster mining difficulty retargeting. Due to its underlying similarities to Bitcoin, Litecoin has historically been referred to as the "silver to Bitcoin's gold."[6][7][8] In 2022, Litecoin added optional privacy features via soft fork through the MWEB (MimbleWimble extension block) upgrade.[8][9]

Design
Units and divisibility

This section does not cite any sources. Please help improve this section by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.

(April 2024) (Learn how and when to remove this message)
Currency codes for representing litecoin is LTC. Its Unicode character is Ł.

One litecoin is divisible to eight decimal places. Units for smaller amounts of litecoin are:

lites, or millilitecoin (mŁ), equal to 1⁄1000 litecoin,
photons, or microlitecoin (μŁ), equal to 1⁄1000000,
the litoshi, which is the smallest possible division, and named in homage to bitcoin's smallest denomination the satoshi, representing 1⁄100000000 (one hundred millionth) litecoin.
History
Pre-Litecoin
By 2011, Bitcoin mining was largely performed by GPUs.[10] This raised concern in some users that mining now had a high barrier to entry, and that CPU resources were becoming obsolete and worthless for mining. Using code from Bitcoin, a new alternative currency was created called Tenebrix (TBX).

Tenebrix replaced the SHA-256 rounds in Bitcoin's mining algorithm with the scrypt function,[11] which had been specifically designed in 2009 to be expensive to accelerate with FPGA or ASIC chips.[12] This would allow Tenebrix to have been "GPU-resistant", and utilize the available CPU resources from bitcoin miners. Tenebrix itself was a successor project to an earlier cryptocurrency which replaced Bitcoin's issuance schedule with a constant block reward (thus creating an unlimited money supply).[11] However, the developers included a clause in the code that would allow them to claim 7.7 million TBX for themselves at no cost, which was criticized by users.[13]

To address this, Charlie Lee, a Google employee who would later become engineering director at Coinbase,[14] created an alternative version of Tenebrix called Fairbrix (FBX).[3] Litecoin inherits the scrypt mining algorithm from Fairbrix, but returns to the limited money supply of Bitcoin, with other changes.

Creation and launch
Lee released Litecoin via an open-source client on GitHub on October 7, 2011.[15] The Litecoin network went live on October 13, 2011.

Litecoin was a source code fork of the Bitcoin Core client, originally differing by having a decreased block generation time (2.5 minutes), increased maximum number of coins, different hashing algorithm (scrypt, instead of SHA-256), faster difficulty retarget, and a slightly modified GUI.[citation needed]

2011–2016
After launch, the early growth of Litecoin was aided by its increasing exchange availability and liquidity on early exchanges such as BTC-e. During the month of November 2013, the aggregate value of Litecoin experienced massive growth which included a 100% leap within 24 hours.[16][17]

In early 2014, Lee suggested merge mining (auxPOW) Dogecoin with Litecoin to the Dogecoin community at large. In September 2014, Dogecoin began merge-mining with Litecoin.

[18]

2017–2021
In 2020, PayPal added the ability for users to purchase a derivative of Litecoin along with Bitcoin, Ethereum and Bitcoin Cash which could not be withdrawn or spent as part of its Crypto feature.[19][20]

In September 2021, a fake press release was published on GlobeNewswire announcing a partnership between Litecoin and Walmart. This caused the price of Litecoin to increase by around 30%, before the press release was revealed as a hoax.[21]

2022–present
In May 2022, MWEB (Mimblewimble Extension Blocks) upgrade was activated on the Litecoin network as a soft fork. This upgrade provides users with the option of sending confidential Litecoin transactions, in which the amount being sent is only known between the sender and receiver.[22][non-primary source needed]

In June 2022, PayPal added the ability for users to transfer Litecoin along with Bitcoin, Ethereum and Bitcoin Cash between PayPal to other wallets and exchanges.

[23][non-primary source needed]

Differences from Bitcoin
Litecoin is different in some ways from Bitcoin:

The targeted block time is every 2.5 minutes for Litecoin, as opposed to Bitcoin's 10 minutes. This allows Litecoin to confirm transactions four times faster than Bitcoin.[24]
Scrypt, an alternative proof-of-work algorithm, is used for Litecoin. According to Motherboard, "Scrypt was chosen because it theoretically prevents the use of ASICs, those specialized chips that greatly increase mining power and efficiency (though there is debate over the validity of this claim).".[25]
Litecoin is merge mined with another prominent cryptocurrency, Dogecoin.[26]
Litecoin has a maximum circulating supply of Ł84,000,000, which is four times larger than Bitcoin's maximum circulating supply of ₿21,000,000.[citation needed]
MWEB optional privacy was added to Litecoin's base layer in May 2022 via soft fork.[9] This allows amounts held within wallets and transaction amounts within MWEB to be private.

[27]
Third party vendors providing point of sale infrastructure for Litecoin include BitPay.[28]

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
WhopperCoin
WhopperCoin was a cryptocurrency launched by the Russian branch of Burger King as a loyalty program in the summer of 2017. It was primarily notable for being the first issuance of branded cryptocurrency by a major company and the first form of loyalty points that could be traded freely; the BBC noted that Burger King was the "first major corporate brand to issue its own crypto-cash", with WhopperCoin turning a burger into an "investment vehicle".[2] It was hosted on the Waves blockchain platform.[3][4]

The cryptocurrency did not prove successful: while WhopperCoins had traded at prices as high as USD$0.14 in September 2017, by January 2018 the price had fallen to less than USD$0.002,[5] and by September 2019 trading volume had declined to zero.[6]

Implementation
WhopperCoin transactions were hosted on the Waves platform, a rival to Ethereum.

[3][2][5][7] Waves ran a blockchain ledger (a distributed record of transactions resistant to tampering or alteration), which tracked ownership of WhopperCoin and recorded transactions.[2][7] One billion coins were initially issued.[2][8][9][10]

WhopperCoins were permitted to be bought, sold or given away freely,[2][10] which meant that they could be used as financial instruments and traded on exchanges alongside other cryptocurrencies.[2][8] In June 2017, Burger King Russia had announced that they would begin accepting Bitcoin.[8] In August, Ivan Shestov, the head of external communications at Burger King Russia, referred to WhopperCoin as an "investment tool" and was quoted as saying that "eating Whoppers now is a strategy for financial prosperity tomorrow".

[2][3][10]

The specifics of implementation were initially unclear;[1] on 24 August, New York magazine and Fortune cited a Russian-language article from Rusbase[8][11] saying that customers would receive one WhopperCoin for each Whopper purchased[1][8] and that its initial use would be as a loyalty program where WhopperCoins could be used to purchase menu items. At that time, the company had not established an exchange rate at which WhopperCoins could be used to make Burger King purchases. On 29 August, however, sources began to reflect that one WhopperCoin would be given out for each ruble spent on a Whopper, and that a Whopper would be able to be purchased for 1,700 WhopperCoins.[2][10][12][13] This meant that one free Whopper could be obtained for every "five or six" purchased with normal currency.[2] The BBC also added that customers would be able to claim coins by scanning their receipts on a smartphone, with Android and iPhone apps expected to be released in September 2017.

[2][9]

Impact
In September 2017, immediately after its launch, one WhopperCoin was valued at USD$0.14.[5] Previously, Burger King had pioneered the use of cryptocurrency in the fast food industry with its Netherlands branch accepting Bitcoin in 2016.[6] Additionally, reports in June 2017 said that Burger King Russia "would be accepting bitcoin as payment".[1] However, at the time of WhopperCoin's launch, CNBC noted that previous attempts toward cryptocurrency adoption by Burger King Russia had been poorly received by the Russian government, with 2016 reports "suggesting users could even face jail time under proposed legislation".[3] However, subsequent statements showed support for the idea, including an interview where First Deputy Prime Minister Igor Shuvalov said "I am a supporter, a cryptoround [sic] must exist."[3] However, at the time, no legal framework for cryptocurrency existed in Russia,[7] where it remained illegal to use cryptocurrencies as payment for any goods or services.[7]

WhopperCoin was not widely given serious consideration.

Upon its release, Fortune contrasted it with "cryptocurrencies you may actually use",[1] while New York magazine sardonically praised it as a "way to satiate both your appetite and your need for rather useless virtual money".[11] The Verge described Shestov's claim that "eating Whoppers now is a strategy for financial prosperity tomorrow" as a "bit of a stretch";[14] in September 2017, Business Insider cited it as evidence that the "ICO craze" had "reached its zenith".[15] Marketing Week said that cryptocurrencies had been "described at one extreme as gimmicks that simply make good fodder for PR stunts, and at the other as a new economic paradigm", and described Burger King Russia's move as "capitalising on the blockchain buzz".[12]

Despite this, WhopperCoin's uniqueness was widely discussed. Adweek praised Burger King's "knack for hijacking the hype train"[9] and some pointed to it as a potential new direction for corporate loyalty programs.

[2][13] Garrick Hileman, a research fellow at the Cambridge Centre for Alternative Finance, compared them favorably to airline miles programs, which cannot be traded as financial instruments (or, generally, with any entity besides the issuing company and its affiliates); the possibility of trading WhopperCoin against currencies or other assets had the potential to make them "more compelling than a standard loyalty scheme".[2][13] Emin Gun Sirer, an associate professor at Cornell University, said that rewards points were "actually a good use case for blockchains" and WhopperCoin was likely the first of many similar programs. In a conversation with the BBC, he cautioned that they also had the potential to be used as a vehicle for ransomware and money laundering.[2]

Demise
Despite initial fanfare, the program was not successful. In January 2018, the price of a WhopperCoin (which had been USD$0.14 in September 2017) had fallen to less than USD$0.002.

[5] While the token had a dedicated asset page on Waves' website at its launch in 2017,[9][14] Verdict reported that "despite a strong start, the Whoppercoin fad died down fairly quickly".[5] Although later cryptocurrency initiatives by Burger King would see success (the German branch began accepting Bitcoin in 2019),[6] WhopperCoin did not.

As of September 2019, WHO trading volume stood at zero.[6] In October 2019, Wired noted that WhopperCoin had "long lost its sizzle", along with thousands of similarly ambitious cryptocurrency ventures, many of which it characterized as "blockchain memes".[16]

**Bitcoin** (abbreviation: **BTC** ; [sign](/wiki/Currency_symbol "Currency
symbol"): **₿**) is the first [decentralized](/wiki/Decentralized_application
"Decentralized application") [cryptocurrency](/wiki/Cryptocurrency
"Cryptocurrency"). [Nodes](/wiki/Node_\(networking\) "Node \(networking\)") in
the [peer-to-peer](/wiki/Peer-to-peer "Peer-to-peer") [bitcoin
network](/wiki/Bitcoin_network "Bitcoin network") verify transactions through
[cryptography](/wiki/Cryptography "Cryptography") and record them in a public
[distributed ledger](/wiki/Distributed_ledger "Distributed ledger"), called a
[blockchain](/wiki/Blockchain "Blockchain"), without central oversight.
[Consensus](/wiki/Consensus_\(computer_science\) "Consensus \(computer
science\)") between nodes is achieved using a computationally intensive
process based on [proof of work](/wiki/Proof_of_work "Proof of work"), called
[mining](/wiki/Bitcoin_mining "Bitcoin mining"), that guarantees the security
of the bitcoin blockchain.

Mining consumes large quantities of electricity and
has been criticized for [its environmental
impact](/wiki/Environmental_impact_of_bitcoin "Environmental impact of
bitcoin").[5]

Based on a [free market](/wiki/Free_market "Free market") ideology, bitcoin
was invented in 2008 by [Satoshi Nakamoto](/wiki/Satoshi_Nakamoto "Satoshi
Nakamoto"), an unknown person.[6] Use of bitcoin as a
[currency](/wiki/Currency "Currency") began in 2009,[7] with the release of
its [open-source implementation](/wiki/Open-source_software "Open-source
software").[8]: ch. 1 In 2021, [El Salvador adopted it as legal
tender](/wiki/Bitcoin_in_El_Salvador "Bitcoin in El Salvador").[4] Bitcoin is
currently used more as a [store of value](/wiki/Store_of_value "Store of
value") and less as a [medium of exchange](/wiki/Medium_of_exchange "Medium of
exchange") or [unit of account](/wiki/Unit_of_account "Unit of account").

It
is mostly seen as an [investment](/wiki/Investment "Investment") and has been
described by many scholars as an [economic bubble](/wiki/Economic_bubble
"Economic bubble").[9] As bitcoin is [pseudonymous](/wiki/Pseudonym
"Pseudonym"), [its use by criminals](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_and_crime
"Cryptocurrency and crime") has attracted the attention of regulators, leading
to [its ban by several
countries](/wiki/Legality_of_cryptocurrency_by_country_or_territory "Legality
of cryptocurrency by country or territory") as of
2021[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bitcoin&action=edit).[10]

## History

Main article: [History of bitcoin](/wiki/History_of_bitcoin "History of
bitcoin")

### Background

Before bitcoin, several [digital cash technologies](/wiki/Digital_cash
"Digital cash") were released, starting with [David Chaum](/wiki/David_Chaum
"David Chaum")'s [ecash](/wiki/Ecash "Ecash") in the 1980s.

[11] The idea that
solutions to computational puzzles could have some value was first proposed by
cryptographers [Cynthia Dwork](/wiki/Cynthia_Dwork "Cynthia Dwork") and [Moni
Naor](/wiki/Moni_Naor "Moni Naor") in 1992.[11] The concept was [independently
rediscovered](/wiki/Multiple_discovery "Multiple discovery") by [Adam
Back](/wiki/Adam_Back "Adam Back") who developed [Hashcash](/wiki/Hashcash
"Hashcash"), a [proof-of-work](/wiki/Proof-of-work "Proof-of-work") scheme for
[spam control](/wiki/Anti-spam_techniques "Anti-spam techniques") in 1997.

[11]
The first proposals for distributed digital scarcity-based
[cryptocurrencies](/wiki/Cryptocurrencies "Cryptocurrencies") came from
[cypherpunks](/wiki/Cypherpunk "Cypherpunk") [Wei Dai](/wiki/Wei_Dai "Wei
Dai") (b-money) and [Nick Szabo](/wiki/Nick_Szabo "Nick Szabo") ([bit
gold](/wiki/Bit_gold "Bit gold")) in 1998.[12] In 2004, [Hal
Finney](/wiki/Hal_Finney_\(cypherpunk\) "Hal Finney \(cypherpunk\)") developed
the first currency based on reusable proof of work.[13] These various attempts
were not successful:[11] Chaum's concept required centralized control and no
banks wanted to sign on, Hashcash had no protection against [double-
spending](/wiki/Double-spending "Double-spending"), while b-money and bit gold
were not resistant to [Sybil attacks](/wiki/Sybil_attack "Sybil attack").[11]

### 2008–2009: Creation

External image  
---  
!

[image
icon](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/61/Searchtool.svg/16px-
Searchtool.svg.png) [Cover page of _The Times_ 3 January 2009 showing the
headline used in the genesis block](https://www.thetimes03jan2009.com/wp-
content/uploads/2015/03/genesis-block-newspaper-bitcoin.jpg)  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8f/Bitcoin_old.png)](/wiki/File:Bitcoin_old.png)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Bitcoin.png/90px-
Bitcoin.png)](/wiki/File:Bitcoin.png)

Bitcoin logos made by Satoshi Nakamoto in 2009 (left) and 2010 (right).

The domain name _bitcoin.org_ was registered on 18 August 2008.

[14] On 31
October 2008, a link to a [white paper](/wiki/White_paper "White paper")
authored by [Satoshi Nakamoto](/wiki/Satoshi_Nakamoto "Satoshi Nakamoto")
titled _Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System_ was posted to a
cryptography mailing list.[15] Nakamoto implemented the bitcoin software as
[open-source code](/wiki/Open-source_software "Open-source software") and
released it in January 2009.[7] Nakamoto's identity remains unknown.[6] All
individual components of bitcoin originated in earlier academic
literature.[11] Nakamoto's innovation was their complex interplay resulting in
the first decentralized, Sybil resistant, [Byzantine
fault](/wiki/Byzantine_fault "Byzantine fault") tolerant digital cash system,
that would eventually be referred to as the first blockchain.[11][16]
Nakamoto's paper was not [peer reviewed](/wiki/Peer_review "Peer review") and
was initially ignored by academics, who argued that it could not work.

[11]

On 3 January 2009, the bitcoin network was created when Nakamoto mined the
starting block of the chain, known as the _[genesis
block](/wiki/Genesis_\(blockchain\) "Genesis \(blockchain\)")_.[17] Embedded
in this block was the text "The Times 03/Jan/2009 Chancellor on brink of
[second bailout for banks](/wiki/2009_United_Kingdom_bank_rescue_package "2009
United Kingdom bank rescue package")", which is the date and headline of an
issue of _[The Times](/wiki/The_Times "The Times")_ newspaper.[7] Nine days
later, Hal Finney received the first bitcoin transaction: ten bitcoins from
Nakamoto.[18] Wei Dai and Nick Szabo were also early supporters.

[17] On May
22, 2010, the first known [commercial transaction](/wiki/Financial_transaction
"Financial transaction") using bitcoin occurred when programmer Laszlo Hanyecz
bought two [Papa John's](/wiki/Papa_John%27s "Papa John's") pizzas for
₿10,000, in what would later be celebrated as "Bitcoin Pizza Day".[19]

### 2010–2012: Early growth

[Blockchain analysts](/wiki/Blockchain#Blockchain_analysis "Blockchain")
estimate that Nakamoto had mined about one million bitcoins[20] before
disappearing in 2010 when he handed the network alert key and control of the
[code repository](/wiki/Software_repository "Software repository") over to
[Gavin Andresen](/wiki/Gavin_Andresen "Gavin Andresen"). Andresen later became
lead developer at the [Bitcoin Foundation](/wiki/Bitcoin_Foundation "Bitcoin
Foundation"),[21][22] an [organization](/wiki/List_of_bitcoin_organizations
"List of bitcoin organizations") founded in September 2012 to promote
bitcoin.

[23]

After early "[proof-of-concept](/wiki/Proof-of-concept "Proof-of-concept")"
transactions, the first major users of bitcoin were [black
markets](/wiki/Black_market "Black market"), such as the [dark
web](/wiki/Dark_web "Dark web") [Silk Road](/wiki/Silk_Road_\(marketplace\)
"Silk Road \(marketplace\)"). During its 30 months of existence, beginning in
February 2011, Silk Road exclusively accepted bitcoins as payment, transacting
₿9.9 million, worth about $214 million.[24]: 222

### 2013–2014: First regulatory actions

In March 2013, the US [Financial Crimes Enforcement
Network](/wiki/Financial_Crimes_Enforcement_Network "Financial Crimes
Enforcement Network") (FinCEN) established regulatory guidelines for
"decentralized virtual currencies" such as bitcoin, classifying American
bitcoin miners who sell their generated bitcoins as [money services
businesses](/wiki/Money_services_business "Money services business"), subject
to registration and other legal obligations.

[25] In May 2013, US authorities
seized the unregistered [exchange](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_exchange
"Cryptocurrency exchange") [Mt. Gox](/wiki/Mt._Gox "Mt. Gox").[26] In June
2013, the US [Drug Enforcement
Administration](/wiki/Drug_Enforcement_Administration "Drug Enforcement
Administration") seized ₿11.02 from a man attempting to use them to buy
illegal substances. This marked the first time a government agency had seized
bitcoins.[27] The FBI seized about ₿30,000 in October 2013 from Silk Road,
following the arrest of its founder [Ross Ulbricht](/wiki/Ross_Ulbricht "Ross
Ulbricht").[28]

In December 2013, the [People's Bank of China](/wiki/People%27s_Bank_of_China
"People's Bank of China") prohibited Chinese financial institutions from using
bitcoin.[29] After the announcement, the value of bitcoin dropped,[30] and
[Baidu](/wiki/Baidu "Baidu") no longer accepted bitcoins for certain
services.

[31] Buying real-world goods with any virtual currency had been
illegal in China since at least 2009.[32]

### 2015–2019

Research produced by the [University of
Cambridge](/wiki/University_of_Cambridge "University of Cambridge") estimated
that in 2017, there were 2.9 to 5.8 million unique users using a
[cryptocurrency wallet](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_wallet "Cryptocurrency wallet"),
most of them using bitcoin.[33] In August 2017, the [SegWit](/wiki/SegWit
"SegWit") software upgrade was activated. Segwit was intended to support the
[Lightning Network](/wiki/Lightning_Network "Lightning Network") as well as
improve [scalability](/wiki/Scalability "Scalability").

[34] SegWit opponents,
who supported larger blocks as a scalability solution,
[forked](/wiki/Fork_\(blockchain\) "Fork \(blockchain\)") to create [Bitcoin
Cash](/wiki/Bitcoin_Cash "Bitcoin Cash"), one of many [forks of
bitcoin](/wiki/List_of_bitcoin_forks "List of bitcoin forks").[35]

In December 2017, the first [futures](/wiki/Futures_contract "Futures
contract") on bitcoin was introduced by the [Chicago Mercantile
Exchange](/wiki/Chicago_Mercantile_Exchange "Chicago Mercantile Exchange")
(CME).[36]

In February 2018, the price crashed after China imposed a complete ban on
Bitcoin trading.[37] The percentage of bitcoin trading in the Chinese
[renminbi](/wiki/Renminbi "Renminbi") fell from over 90% in September 2017 to
less than 1% in June 2018.[38] During the same year, Bitcoin prices were
negatively affected by several hacks or thefts from cryptocurrency
exchanges.[39]

### 2020–present

[!

[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Bitcoin_usd_price.svg/220px-
Bitcoin_usd_price.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Bitcoin_usd_price.svg)Bitcoin price in
US dollars

In 2020, some major companies and institutions started to acquire bitcoin:
[MicroStrategy](/wiki/MicroStrategy "MicroStrategy") invested $250 million in
bitcoin as a [treasury reserve asset](/wiki/Treasury_management "Treasury
management"),[40] [Square, Inc.](/wiki/Square,_Inc. "Square, Inc."), $50
million,[41] and [MassMutual](/wiki/MassMutual "MassMutual"), $100
million.[42] In November 2020, [PayPal](/wiki/PayPal "PayPal") added support
for bitcoin in the US.[43]

In February 2021, Bitcoin's [market
capitalization](/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization") reached
$1 trillion for the first time.

[44] In November 2021, the
[Taproot](/wiki/Taproot_\(fork\) "Taproot \(fork\)") [soft-fork](/wiki/Soft-
fork "Soft-fork") upgrade was activated, adding support for [Schnorr
signatures](/wiki/Schnorr_signature "Schnorr signature"), improved
functionality of [smart contracts](/wiki/Smart_contract "Smart contract") and
[Lightning Network](/wiki/Lightning_Network "Lightning Network").[45] Before,
Bitcoin only used a custom [elliptic curve](/wiki/Elliptic_curve_cryptography
"Elliptic curve cryptography") with the [ECDSA](/wiki/ECDSA "ECDSA") algorithm
to produce [signatures](/wiki/Digital_signature "Digital signature").[46]: 101
In September 2021, Bitcoin became [legal tender](/wiki/Legal_tender "Legal
tender") in [El Salvador](/wiki/Bitcoin_in_El_Salvador "Bitcoin in El
Salvador"), alongside the US dollar.

[4] In October 2021, the first bitcoin
futures [exchange-traded fund](/wiki/Exchange-traded_fund "Exchange-traded
fund") (ETF), called BITO, from [ProShares](/wiki/ProShares "ProShares") was
approved by the [SEC](/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission "U.S.
Securities and Exchange Commission") and listed on the
[CME](/wiki/Chicago_Mercantile_Exchange "Chicago Mercantile Exchange").[47]

In May and June 2022, the bitcoin price fell following the collapses of
[TerraUSD](/wiki/Terra_\(blockchain\) "Terra \(blockchain\)"), a
[stablecoin](/wiki/Stablecoin "Stablecoin"),[48] and the [Celsius
Network](/wiki/Celsius_Network "Celsius Network"), a cryptocurrency loan
company.[49][50]

In 2023, ordinals—[non-fungible tokens](/wiki/Non-fungible_token "Non-fungible
token") (NFTs)—on Bitcoin, went live.

[51] In January 2024, the first 11 US
[spot](/wiki/Spot_market "Spot market") bitcoin [ETFs](/wiki/Exchange-
traded_fund "Exchange-traded fund") began trading, offering direct exposure to
bitcoin for the first time on American stock exchanges.[52][53] As of June
2023 River Financial estimated that Bitcoin had 81.7 million users, about 1%
of the global population.[54]

## Design

Main article: [Bitcoin protocol](/wiki/Bitcoin_protocol "Bitcoin protocol")

### Units and divisibility

The [unit of account](/wiki/Unit_of_account "Unit of account") of the bitcoin
system is the _bitcoin_. It is most commonly represented with the
[symbol](/wiki/Currency_symbol "Currency symbol") ₿[1] and the [currency
code](/wiki/Currency_code "Currency code") BTC.

However, the BTC code does not
conform to [ISO 4217](/wiki/ISO_4217 "ISO 4217") as BT is the country code of
Bhutan,[55] and ISO 4217 requires the first letter used in global commodities
to be 'X'.[55] XBT, a code that conforms to [ISO 4217](/wiki/ISO_4217 "ISO
4217") though not officially part of it,[55] is used by [Bloomberg
L.P.](/wiki/Bloomberg_L.P. "Bloomberg L.P.")[56]

No uniform [capitalization](/wiki/Capitalization "Capitalization") convention
exists; some sources use _Bitcoin_ , capitalized, to refer to the technology
and [network](/wiki/Computer_network "Computer network"), and _bitcoin_ ,
lowercase, for the unit of account.

[57] The _[Cambridge Advanced Learner's
Dictionary](/wiki/Cambridge_Advanced_Learner%27s_Dictionary "Cambridge
Advanced Learner's Dictionary")_ and the _[Oxford Advanced Learner's
Dictionary](/wiki/Oxford_Advanced_Learner%27s_Dictionary "Oxford Advanced
Learner's Dictionary")_ use the capitalized and lowercase variants without
distinction.[58][59]

One bitcoin is divisible to eight decimal places.[8]: ch. 5 Units for smaller
amounts of bitcoin are the millibitcoin (mBTC), equal to 1⁄1000 bitcoin, and
the satoshi[a] (sat), representing 1⁄100000000 (one hundred millionth)
bitcoin, the smallest amount possible.[2] 100,000 satoshis are one mBTC.

[60]

### Blockchain

Further information: [Blockchain § Structure and
design](/wiki/Blockchain#Structure_and_design "Blockchain")

As a [decentralized](/wiki/Decentralization "Decentralization") system,
bitcoin operates without a central authority or single administrator,[61] so
that anyone can create a new bitcoin address and transact without needing any
approval.[8]: ch. 1 This is accomplished through a specialized [distributed
ledger](/wiki/Distributed_ledger "Distributed ledger") called a
_[blockchain](/wiki/Blockchain "Blockchain")_ that records bitcoin
transactions.[62]

The blockchain is implemented as an ordered list of _blocks_. Each block
contains a [SHA-256](/wiki/SHA-256 "SHA-256")
[hash](/wiki/Cryptographic_hash_function "Cryptographic hash function") of the
previous block,[62] chaining them in chronological order.[8]: ch. 7 [62] The
blockchain is maintained by a [peer-to-peer](/wiki/Peer-to-peer "Peer-to-
peer") network.

[24]: 215–219 Individual blocks, public addresses, and
transactions within blocks are public information, and can be examined using a
blockchain explorer.[63]

Nodes validate and broadcast transactions, each maintaining a copy of the
blockchain for ownership verification.[64] A new block is created every 10
minutes on average, updating the blockchain across all nodes without central
oversight. This process tracks bitcoin spending, ensuring each bitcoin is
[spent only once](/wiki/Double-spending "Double-spending"). Unlike a
traditional ledger that tracks physical currency, bitcoins exist digitally as
[unspent outputs of transactions](/wiki/Unspent_outputs_of_transactions
"Unspent outputs of transactions").[8]: ch. 5

### Addresses and transactions

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Bitcoin_Transaction_Visual.svg/220px-
Bitcoin_Transaction_Visual.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Bitcoin_Transaction_Visual.svg)Simplified
chain of ownership. In practice, a transaction can have more than one input
and more than one output.

[65]

In the blockchain, bitcoins are linked to specific addresses that are hashes
of a [public key](/wiki/Public_key "Public key"). Creating an address involves
generating a random [private key](/wiki/Private_key "Private key") and then
computing the corresponding address. This process is almost instant, but the
reverse (finding the private key for a given address) is nearly
impossible.[8]: ch. 4 Publishing a bitcoin address does not risk its private
key, and it is extremely unlikely to accidentally generate a used key with
funds. To use bitcoins, owners need their private key to [digitally
sign](/wiki/Digital_signature "Digital signature") transactions, which are
verified by the network using the public key, keeping the private key
secret.[8]: ch. 5

Bitcoin transactions use a [Forth](/wiki/Forth_\(programming_language\) "Forth
\(programming language\)")-like [scripting language](/wiki/Scripting_language
"Scripting language"),[8]: ch. 5 involving one or more inputs and outputs.

When sending bitcoins, a user specifies the recipients' addresses and the
amount for each output. This allows sending bitcoins to several recipients in
a single transaction. To prevent double-spending, each input must refer to a
previous unspent output in the blockchain.[65] Using multiple inputs is
similar to using multiple coins in a cash transaction. As in a cash
transaction, the sum of inputs can exceed the intended sum of payments. In
such a case, an additional output can return the change back to the payer.[65]
Unallocated input satoshis in the transaction become the transaction fee.[65]

Losing a private key means losing access to the bitcoins, with no other proof
of ownership accepted by the [protocol](/wiki/Bitcoin_protocol "Bitcoin
protocol").[24] For instance, in 2013, a user lost ₿7,500, valued at US$7.5
million, by accidentally discarding a [hard drive](/wiki/Hard_disk_drive "Hard
disk drive") with the private key.[66] It is estimated that around 20% of all
bitcoins are lost.

[67] The private key must also be kept secret as its
exposure, such as through a [data breach](/wiki/Data_breach "Data breach"),
can lead to theft of the associated bitcoins.[8]: ch. 10 [68] As of December
2017[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bitcoin&action=edit),
approximately ₿980,000 had been stolen from [cryptocurrency
exchanges](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_exchange "Cryptocurrency exchange").[69]

### Mining

See also: [Bitcoin protocol § Mining](/wiki/Bitcoin_protocol#Mining "Bitcoin
protocol")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Argo_Blockchain_Mirabel_Facility.jpg/220px-
Argo_Blockchain_Mirabel_Facility.jpg)](/wiki/File:Argo_Blockchain_Mirabel_Facility.jpg)Bitcoin
mining [facility](/wiki/Data_center "Data center") with large amounts of
mining hardware

The mining process in Bitcoin involves maintaining the blockchain through
computer [processing power](/wiki/Processing_power "Processing power").

Miners
group and broadcast new transactions into blocks, which are then verified by
the network.[62] Each block must contain a proof of work (PoW) to be
accepted,[62] involving finding a [nonce](/wiki/Cryptographic_nonce
"Cryptographic nonce") number that, combined with the block content, produces
a [hash](/wiki/Cryptographic_hash "Cryptographic hash") numerically smaller
than the network's _difficulty target_.[8]: ch. 8 This PoW is simple to verify
but hard to generate, requiring many attempts.[8]: ch. 8 PoW forms the basis
of Bitcoin's [consensus mechanism](/wiki/Consensus_\(computer_science\)
"Consensus \(computer science\)").[70]

The difficulty of generating a block is [deterministically
adjusted](/wiki/Deterministic_algorithm "Deterministic algorithm") based on
the [mining power on the network](/wiki/Hashrate "Hashrate") by changing the
difficulty target, which is recalibrated every 2,016 blocks (approximately two
weeks) to maintain an average time of ten minutes between new blocks.

The
process requires significant computational power and specialized
[hardware](/wiki/Computer_hardware "Computer hardware").[8]: ch. 8 [71]

Miners who successfully find a new block can collect transaction fees from the
included transactions and a set reward in bitcoins.[72] To claim this reward,
a special transaction called a _coinbase_ is included in the block, with the
miner as the payee. All bitcoins in existence have been created through this
type of transaction.[8]: ch. 8 This reward is halved every 210,000 blocks
until ₿21 million,[b] with new bitcoin issuance slated to end around 2140.
Afterward, miners will only earn from transaction fees. These fees are
determined by the transaction's size and the amount of data stored, measured
in satoshis per byte.[73][65][8]: ch. 8

The proof of work system and the chaining of blocks make blockchain
modifications very difficult, as altering one block requires changing all
subsequent blocks. As more blocks are added, modifying older blocks becomes
increasingly challenging.

[74][62] In case of disagreement, nodes trust the
longest chain, which required the greatest amount of effort to produce.[70] To
tamper or censor the ledger, one needs to control the majority of the global
[hashrate](/wiki/Hashrate "Hashrate").[70] The high cost required to reach
this level of computational power guarantees the
[security](/wiki/Computer_security "Computer security") of the bitcoin
blockchain.[70]

[Bitcoin mining's environmental impact](/wiki/Environmental_impact_of_bitcoin
"Environmental impact of bitcoin") is controversial and has attracted the
attention of regulators, [leading to restrictions or incentives in various
jurisdictions](/wiki/Legality_of_cryptocurrency_by_country_or_territory
"Legality of cryptocurrency by country or territory").

[75] As of
2022[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bitcoin&action=edit),
a [non-peer-reviewed](/wiki/Non-peer-reviewed "Non-peer-reviewed") study by
the [Cambridge Centre for Alternative
Finance](/wiki/Cambridge_Centre_for_Alternative_Finance "Cambridge Centre for
Alternative Finance") (CCAF) estimated that bitcoin mining represented 0.4% of
[global electricity consumption](/wiki/World_energy_supply_and_consumption
"World energy supply and consumption").[76] Another 2022 non-peer-reviewed
commentary published in _[Joule](/wiki/Joule_\(journal\) "Joule \(journal\)")_
estimated that bitcoin mining was responsible for 0.2% of world greenhouse gas
emissions.[77] About half of the electricity used is generated through [fossil
fuels](/wiki/Fossil_fuel "Fossil fuel").[78] Moreover, mining hardware's short
lifespan results in [electronic waste](/wiki/Electronic_waste "Electronic
waste").

[79] The amount of electrical energy consumed, and the e-waste
generated, is comparable to that of Greece and the Netherlands,
respectively.[79][77]

### Privacy and fungibility

Bitcoin is [pseudonymous](/wiki/Pseudonym "Pseudonym"), with funds linked to
addresses, not real-world identities. While the owners of these addresses are
not directly identified, all transactions are public on the blockchain.
Patterns of use, like spending coins from multiple inputs, can hint at a
common owner. Public data can sometimes be matched with known address
owners.[80] [Bitcoin exchanges](/wiki/List_of_bitcoin_companies "List of
bitcoin companies") might also need to collect personal data as per legal
requirements.[81] For enhanced [privacy](/wiki/Privacy_and_blockchain "Privacy
and blockchain"), users can generate a new address for each transaction.[82]

In the Bitcoin network, each bitcoin is treated equally, ensuring basic
[fungibility](/wiki/Fungibility "Fungibility"). However, users and
applications can choose to differentiate between bitcoins.

While wallets and
software treat all bitcoins the same, each bitcoin's transaction history is
recorded on the blockchain. This public record allows for [chain
analysis](/wiki/Blockchain_analysis "Blockchain analysis"), where users can
identify and potentially reject bitcoins from controversial sources.[83] For
example, in 2012, Mt. Gox froze accounts containing bitcoins identified as
stolen.[84]

### Wallets

For broader coverage of this topic, see [Cryptocurrency
wallet](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_wallet "Cryptocurrency wallet").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Bitcoin-
core-v0.10.0.png/161px-Bitcoin-core-v0.10.0.png)](/wiki/File:Bitcoin-
core-v0.10.0.png)

Screenshot of [Bitcoin Core](/wiki/Bitcoin_Core "Bitcoin Core")

[!

[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Sample_Bitcoin_paper_wallet.png/220px-
Sample_Bitcoin_paper_wallet.png)](/wiki/File:Sample_Bitcoin_paper_wallet.png)

A paper wallet with the address as a [QR code](/wiki/QR_code "QR code") while
the private key is hidden

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/10elqpi.jpg/199px-10elqpi.jpg)](/wiki/File:10elqpi.jpg)

A hardware wallet which processes bitcoin transactions without exposing
private keys

Bitcoin wallets were the first [cryptocurrency
wallets](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_wallet "Cryptocurrency wallet"), enabling users
to store the information necessary to transact bitcoins.[85][8]: ch. 1,
glossary The first wallet program, simply named _Bitcoin_ , and sometimes
referred to as the _Satoshi client_ , was released in 2009 by Nakamoto as
[open-source software](/wiki/Open-source_software "Open-source software").

[7]
[Bitcoin Core](/wiki/Bitcoin_Core "Bitcoin Core") is among the best known
[clients](/wiki/Client_\(computing\) "Client \(computing\)").
[Forks](/wiki/Fork_\(software_development\) "Fork \(software development\)")
of Bitcoin Core exist such as [Bitcoin Unlimited](/wiki/Bitcoin_Unlimited
"Bitcoin Unlimited").[86] Wallets can be full clients, with a full copy of the
blockchain to check the validity of mined blocks,[8]: ch. 1 or lightweight
clients, just to send and receive transactions without a local copy of the
entire blockchain.[87] Third-party internet services called online wallets
store users' credentials on their servers, making them susceptible of
hacks.[88] Cold storage protects bitcoins from such hacks by keeping private
keys offline, either through specialized hardware wallets or paper
printouts.[89][8]: ch. 4

### Scalability and decentralization challenges

Nakamoto limited the block size to one [megabyte](/wiki/Megabyte
"Megabyte").

[90] The limited block size and frequency can lead to delayed
processing of transactions, increased fees and a [Bitcoin scalability
problem](/wiki/Bitcoin_scalability_problem "Bitcoin scalability problem").[91]
The [Lightning Network](/wiki/Lightning_Network "Lightning Network"), [second-
layer](/wiki/Abstraction_layer "Abstraction layer") [routing](/wiki/Routing
"Routing") network, is a potential scaling solution.[8]: ch. 8

Research shows a trend towards centralization in bitcoin as miners join
[pools](/wiki/Mining_pool "Mining pool") for stable income.[24]: 215, 219–222
[92]: 3 If a single miner or pool controls more than 50% of the [hashing
power](/wiki/Hashrate "Hashrate"), it would allow them to censor transactions
and double-spend coins.[61] In 2014, mining pool [Ghash.io](/wiki/Ghash.io
"Ghash.io") reached 51% mining power, causing safety concerns, but later
voluntarily capped its power at 39.99% for the benefit of the whole
network.

[93] A few entities also dominate other parts of the ecosystem such as
the client software, online wallets, and simplified payment verification (SPV)
clients.[61]

## Economics and usage

Main article: [Economics of bitcoin](/wiki/Economics_of_bitcoin "Economics of
bitcoin")

### Bitcoin's theoretical roots and ideology

See also: [Crypto-anarchism](/wiki/Crypto-anarchism "Crypto-anarchism")

External videos  
---  
!

[video
icon](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg/16px-
Nuvola_apps_kaboodle.svg.png) [The Declaration Of Bitcoin's
Independence](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XQqZ9b0S0BY), BraveTheWorld,
4:38  
  
According to the [European Central Bank](/wiki/European_Central_Bank "European
Central Bank"), the decentralization of money offered by bitcoin has its
theoretical roots in the [Austrian school of
economics](/wiki/Austrian_school_of_economics "Austrian school of economics"),
especially with [Friedrich von Hayek](/wiki/Friedrich_von_Hayek "Friedrich von
Hayek")'s book _[The Denationalization of
Money](/wiki/The_Denationalization_of_Money "The Denationalization of Money")_
, in which he advocates a complete [free market](/wiki/Free_market "Free
market") in the production, distribution and management of money to end the
monopoly of [central banks](/wiki/Central_banks "Central banks").

[94]: 22
Sociologist [Nigel Dodd](/wiki/Nigel_Dodd "Nigel Dodd"), citing the [crypto-
anarchist](/wiki/Crypto-anarchism "Crypto-anarchism") _Declaration of
Bitcoin's Independence_ , argues that the essence of the bitcoin ideology is
to remove money from social, as well as governmental, control.[95] _[The
Economist](/wiki/The_Economist "The Economist")_ describes bitcoin as "a
techno-anarchist project to create an online version of cash, a way for people
to transact without the possibility of interference from malicious governments
or banks".[96] These philosophical ideas initially attracted
[libertarians](/wiki/Libertarian "Libertarian") and
[anarchists](/wiki/Anarchist "Anarchist").[97] Economist [Paul
Krugman](/wiki/Paul_Krugman "Paul Krugman") argues that cryptocurrencies like
bitcoin are only used by bank skeptics and criminals.[98]

### Recognition as a currency and legal status

[![](//upload.wikimedia.

wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Legal_status_of_bitcoin.svg/300px-
Legal_status_of_bitcoin.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Legal_status_of_bitcoin.svg)Legal
status of bitcoin

**Legal tender** (bitcoin is officially recognized as a medium of exchange)

**Permissive** (legal to use bitcoin, with minimal or no restrictions)

**Restricted** (some legal restrictions on the usage of bitcoin)

**Contentious** (interpretation of old laws, but bitcoin is not directly
prohibited)

**Prohibited** (full or partial prohibition on the use of bitcoin)

**No data** (no information available)

  * [v](/wiki/Template:Legal_status_of_bitcoin "Template:Legal status of bitcoin")
  * [t](/wiki/Template_talk:Legal_status_of_bitcoin "Template talk:Legal status of bitcoin")
  * [e](/wiki/Special:EditPage/Template:Legal_status_of_bitcoin "Special:EditPage/Template:Legal status of bitcoin")

[Money](/wiki/Money "Money") serves three purposes: a [store of
value](/wiki/Store_of_value "Store of value"),

a [medium of
exchange](/wiki/Medium_of_exchange "Medium of exchange"), and a [unit of
account](/wiki/Unit_of_account "Unit of account").[99] According to _The
Economist_ in 2014, bitcoin functions best as a medium of exchange.[99] In
2015, _The Economist_ noted that bitcoins had three qualities useful in a
currency: they are "hard to earn, limited in supply and easy to verify".[100]
However, a 2018 assessment by _The Economist_ stated that cryptocurrencies met
none of these three criteria.[96] Per some researchers, as of
2015[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bitcoin&action=edit),
bitcoin functions more as a [payment system](/wiki/Payment_system "Payment
system") than as a currency.

[24] In 2014, economist [Robert J.
Shiller](/wiki/Robert_J._Shiller "Robert J. Shiller") wrote that bitcoin has
potential as a unit of account for measuring the relative value of goods, as
with Chile's [Unidad de Fomento](/wiki/Unidad_de_Fomento "Unidad de Fomento"),
but that "Bitcoin in its present form ... doesn't really solve any sensible
economic problem".[101] François R. Velde, Senior Economist at the [Chicago
Fed](/wiki/Chicago_Fed "Chicago Fed"), described bitcoin as "an elegant
solution to the problem of creating a digital currency".[102] David
Andolfatto, Vice President at the [Federal Reserve Bank of St.
Louis](/wiki/Federal_Reserve_Bank_of_St._Louis "Federal Reserve Bank of St.
Louis"), stated that bitcoin is a threat to the establishment, which he argues
is a good thing for the [Federal Reserve System](/wiki/Federal_Reserve_System
"Federal Reserve System") and other [central banks](/wiki/Central_bank
"Central bank"), because it prompts these institutions to operate sound
policies.

[103]

The [legal status of
bitcoin](/wiki/Legality_of_cryptocurrency_by_country_or_territory "Legality of
cryptocurrency by country or territory") varies substantially from one
jurisdiction to another. Because of its decentralized nature and its global
presence, regulating bitcoin is difficult. However, the use of bitcoin can be
criminalized, and shutting down exchanges and the peer-to-peer economy in a
given country would constitute a [de facto](/wiki/De_facto "De facto")
ban.[104] The [use of bitcoin by criminals](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_and_crime
"Cryptocurrency and crime") has attracted the attention of financial
regulators, legislative bodies, and law enforcement.[105] Nobel-prize winning
economist [Joseph Stiglitz](/wiki/Joseph_Stiglitz "Joseph Stiglitz") says that
bitcoin's anonymity encourages [money laundering](/wiki/Money_laundering
"Money laundering") and other crimes.[106] This is the main justification
behind bitcoin bans.

[10] As of November
2021[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bitcoin&action=edit),
nine countries applied an absolute ban (Algeria, Bangladesh, China, Egypt,
Iraq, Morocco, Nepal, Qatar, and Tunisia) while another 42 countries had an
implicit ban.[107][_[needs
update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] Bitcoin is only [legal
tender](/wiki/Legal_tender "Legal tender") in [El Salvador](/wiki/El_Salvador
"El Salvador").[4]

### Use for payments

[!

[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/De_Waag_Bitcoin.jpg/220px-
De_Waag_Bitcoin.jpg)](/wiki/File:De_Waag_Bitcoin.jpg)Café in
[Delft](/wiki/Delft "Delft") accepting Bitcoin

As of
2018[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bitcoin&action=edit),
Bitcoin is rarely used in transactions with merchants,[108] but it is popular
to [purchase illegal goods](/wiki/Illicit_trade "Illicit trade")
online.[109][110] Prices are not usually quoted in bitcoin and trades involve
conversions into [fiat](/wiki/Fiat_money "Fiat money") currencies.[24]
Commonly cited reasons for not using Bitcoin include high costs, the inability
to process [chargebacks](/wiki/Chargeback "Chargeback"), high [price
volatility](/wiki/Volatility_\(finance\) "Volatility \(finance\)"), long
transaction times, and [transaction fees](/wiki/Transaction_cost "Transaction
cost") (especially for small purchases).

[108][111] _Bloomberg_ reported that
bitcoin was being used for large-item purchases on the site
[Overstock.com](/wiki/Overstock.com "Overstock.com") and for cross-border
payments to [freelancers](/wiki/Freelancer "Freelancer").[112] As of
2015[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bitcoin&action=edit),
there was little sign of bitcoin use in international
[remittances](/wiki/Remittance "Remittance") despite high fees charged by
banks and [Western Union](/wiki/Western_Union "Western Union") who compete in
this market.[24][113]

In September 2021, the [Bitcoin Law](/wiki/Bitcoin_Law "Bitcoin Law") made
bitcoin [legal tender](/wiki/Legal_tender "Legal tender") in [El
Salvador](/wiki/El_Salvador "El Salvador"), alongside the US dollar.[4] The
adoption has been criticized both internationally and within El
Salvador.

[4][114] In particular, in 2022, the [International Monetary
Fund](/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International Monetary Fund") (IMF)
urged El Salvador to reverse its decision.[115] As of
2022[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bitcoin&action=edit),
the use of [Bitcoin in El Salvador](/wiki/Bitcoin_in_El_Salvador "Bitcoin in
El Salvador") remains low: 80% of businesses refused to accept it despite
being legally required to.[116] In April 2022, the [Central African
Republic](/wiki/Central_African_Republic "Central African Republic") (CAR)
adopted Bitcoin as legal tender alongside the [CFA franc](/wiki/CFA_franc "CFA
franc"),[117] but repealed the reform one year later.[118]

Bitcoin is also used by some governments.

For instance, the [Iranian
government](/wiki/Government_of_Iran "Government of Iran") initially opposed
cryptocurrencies, but later saw them as an opportunity to circumvent
[sanctions](/wiki/Sanctions_against_Iran "Sanctions against Iran").[119] Since
2020, Iran has required local bitcoin miners to sell bitcoin to the [Central
Bank of Iran](/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Iran "Central Bank of Iran"), allowing the
central bank to use it for imports.[120] Some [constituent
states](/wiki/Administrative_division "Administrative division") also accept
tax payments in bitcoin, including [Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado")
([US](/wiki/The_US "The US"))[121] and [Zug](/wiki/Canton_of_Zug "Canton of
Zug") ([Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland "Switzerland")).[122] As of 2023, the
US government owned more than $5 billion worth of seized bitcoin.

[123][124]

### Use for investment and status as an economic bubble

Further information: [Cryptocurrency bubble](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_bubble
"Cryptocurrency bubble")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/El_Salvador_Bitcoin_reserves.png/220px-
El_Salvador_Bitcoin_reserves.png)](/wiki/File:El_Salvador_Bitcoin_reserves.png)Government
website with El Salvador reserves in May 2024

As of
2018[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bitcoin&action=edit),
the overwhelming majority of bitcoin transactions took place on
[cryptocurrency exchanges](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_exchange "Cryptocurrency
exchange").[108] Since 2014, regulated bitcoin funds also allow
[exposure](/wiki/Market_exposure "Market exposure") to the asset or to
[futures](/wiki/Futures_contract "Futures contract") as an
investment.

[125][126] Individuals and companies such as the [Winklevoss
twins](/wiki/Winklevoss_Capital_Management "Winklevoss Capital
Management")[127] and [Elon Musk](/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk")'s companies
[SpaceX](/wiki/SpaceX "SpaceX") and [Tesla](/wiki/Tesla,_Inc. "Tesla, Inc.")
have massively invested in Bitcoin.[128][129] Bitcoin wealth is highly
concentrated, with 0.01% holding 27% of in-circulation currency, as of
2021.[130] As of September
2023[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bitcoin&action=edit),
El Salvador had $76.5 million worth of bitcoin in its [international
reserves](/wiki/Foreign_exchange_reserves "Foreign exchange reserves").

[131]

In 2018, research published in the _[Journal of Monetary
Economics](/wiki/Journal_of_Monetary_Economics "Journal of Monetary
Economics")_ concluded that [price manipulation](/wiki/Market_manipulation
"Market manipulation") occurred during the [Mt. Gox](/wiki/Mt._Gox "Mt. Gox")
bitcoin theft and that the market remained vulnerable to manipulation.[132]
Research published in _[The Journal of Finance](/wiki/The_Journal_of_Finance
"The Journal of Finance")_ also suggested that trading associated with
increases in the amount of the [Tether
cryptocurrency](/wiki/Tether_\(cryptocurrency\) "Tether \(cryptocurrency\)")
and associated trading at the [Bitfinex](/wiki/Bitfinex "Bitfinex") exchange
accounted for about half of the price increase in bitcoin in late
2017.

[133][134]

Bitcoin, along with other cryptocurrencies, has been described as an [economic
bubble](/wiki/Economic_bubble "Economic bubble") by several economists,
including [Nobel Prize in
Economics](/wiki/Nobel_Memorial_Prize_in_Economic_Sciences "Nobel Memorial
Prize in Economic Sciences") laureates, such as [Joseph
Stiglitz](/wiki/Joseph_Stiglitz "Joseph Stiglitz"),[135] [James
Heckman](/wiki/James_Heckman "James Heckman"),[9] and [Paul
Krugman](/wiki/Paul_Krugman "Paul Krugman").[98] Another recipient of the
prize, [Robert Shiller](/wiki/Robert_Shiller "Robert Shiller"), argues that
bitcoin is rather a [fad](/wiki/Fad "Fad") that may become an [asset
class](/wiki/Asset_classes "Asset classes"). He describes its price growth as
an "epidemic", driven by [contagious narratives](/wiki/Social_contagion
"Social contagion").

[136]

According to research published in the _[International Review of Financial
Analysis](/wiki/International_Review_of_Financial_Analysis "International
Review of Financial Analysis")_ in 2018, Bitcoin as an asset is highly
volatile and does not behave like any other conventional asset.[137] According
to one 2022 analysis published in _[The Journal of Alternative
Investments](/wiki/The_Journal_of_Alternative_Investments "The Journal of
Alternative Investments")_ , bitcoin was less volatile than
[oil](/wiki/Price_of_oil "Price of oil"),
[silver](/wiki/Silver_as_an_investment "Silver as an investment"), [US
Treasuries](/wiki/United_States_Treasury_security "United States Treasury
security"), and 190 stocks in the [S&P 500](/wiki/S%26P_500 "S&P 500") during
and after the [2020 stock market crash](/wiki/2020_stock_market_crash "2020
stock market crash").

[138] The term
_[hodl](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hodl#English "wikt:hodl")_ was created
in December 2013 for [holding](/wiki/Buy_and_hold "Buy and hold") Bitcoin
rather than selling it during periods of volatility.[139][140]

Economists, investors, and the [central bank of Estonia](/wiki/Bank_of_Estonia
"Bank of Estonia") have described bitcoin as a potential [Ponzi
scheme](/wiki/Ponzi_scheme "Ponzi scheme").[141][142][143] Legal scholar [Eric
Posner](/wiki/Eric_Posner "Eric Posner") disagrees, however, as "a real Ponzi
scheme takes fraud; bitcoin, by contrast, seems more like a collective
[delusion](/wiki/Delusion "Delusion")".[144] A 2014 [World
Bank](/wiki/World_Bank "World Bank") report also concluded that bitcoin was
not a deliberate Ponzi scheme.

[145]
