**Ethereum** is a [decentralized](/wiki/Decentralization#Blockchain_technology
"Decentralization") [blockchain](/wiki/Blockchain "Blockchain") with [smart
contract](/wiki/Smart_contract "Smart contract") functionality. **Ether**
([abbreviation](/wiki/ISO_4217#Cryptocurrencies "ISO 4217"): **ETH**[a]) is
the native [cryptocurrency](/wiki/Cryptocurrency "Cryptocurrency") of the
platform. Among cryptocurrencies, ether is second only to
[bitcoin](/wiki/Bitcoin "Bitcoin") in [market
capitalization](/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization").[2][3] It
is [open-source software](/wiki/Open-source_software "Open-source software").

Ethereum was conceived in 2013 by [programmer](/wiki/Computer_programming
"Computer programming") [Vitalik Buterin](/wiki/Vitalik_Buterin "Vitalik
Buterin").

[4] Other founders include [Gavin Wood](/wiki/Gavin_Wood "Gavin
Wood"), [Charles Hoskinson](/wiki/Charles_Hoskinson "Charles Hoskinson"),
[Anthony Di Iorio](/wiki/Anthony_Di_Iorio "Anthony Di Iorio"), and [Joseph
Lubin](/wiki/Joseph_Lubin_\(entrepreneur\) "Joseph Lubin
\(entrepreneur\)").[5] In 2014, [development](/wiki/Software_development
"Software development") work began and was [crowdfunded](/wiki/Crowdfunding
"Crowdfunding"), and the network went live on 30 July 2015.[6] Ethereum allows
anyone to deploy permanent and immutable [decentralized
applications](/wiki/Decentralized_application "Decentralized application")
onto it, with which users can interact.

[7] [Decentralized
finance](/wiki/Decentralized_finance "Decentralized finance") (DeFi)
applications provide [financial instruments](/wiki/Financial_instrument
"Financial instrument") that do not directly rely on [financial
intermediaries](/wiki/Financial_intermediary "Financial intermediary") like
[brokerages](/wiki/Brokerage "Brokerage"),
[exchanges](/wiki/Exchange_\(organized_market\) "Exchange \(organized
market\)"), or [banks](/wiki/Bank "Bank"). This facilitates borrowing against
cryptocurrency holdings or lending them out for [interest](/wiki/Interest
"Interest").[8][9] Ethereum also allows users to create and exchange [non-
fungible tokens](/wiki/Non-fungible_token "Non-fungible token") (NFTs), which
are tokens that can be tied to unique digital assets, such as images.
Additionally, many other cryptocurrencies utilize the ERC-20 token standard on
top of the Ethereum blockchain and have utilized the platform for [initial
coin offerings](/wiki/Initial_coin_offering "Initial coin offering").

On 15 September 2022, Ethereum transitioned its [consensus
mechanism](/wiki/Consensus_\(computer_science\) "Consensus \(computer
science\)") from [proof-of-work](/wiki/Proof_of_work "Proof of work") (PoW) to
[proof-of-stake](/wiki/Proof_of_stake "Proof of stake") (PoS) in an upgrade
process known as "the Merge". This has cut Ethereum's energy usage by 99%.[10]

## History

### Founding (2013–2014)

[!

[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Vitalik_Buterin_TechCrunch_London_2015_%28cropped%29.jpg/262px-
Vitalik_Buterin_TechCrunch_London_2015_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vitalik_Buterin_TechCrunch_London_2015_\(cropped\).jpg)Ethereum
co-founder [Vitalik Buterin](/wiki/Vitalik_Buterin "Vitalik Buterin") in 2015

Ethereum was initially described in late 2013 in a [white
paper](/wiki/White_paper "White paper") by [Vitalik
Buterin](/wiki/Vitalik_Buterin "Vitalik Buterin"),[4][11] a programmer and co-
founder of _[Bitcoin Magazine](/wiki/Bitcoin_Magazine "Bitcoin Magazine")_ ,
that described a way to build [decentralized](/wiki/Decentralized
"Decentralized") applications.

[12][13] Buterin argued to the [Bitcoin
Core](/wiki/Bitcoin_Core "Bitcoin Core") developers that blockchain technology
could benefit from other applications besides money and that it needed a more
robust language for application development[14]: 88 that could lead to
attaching[_[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify
"Wikipedia:Please clarify")_] real-world assets, such as stocks and property,
to the blockchain.[15] In 2013, Buterin briefly worked with
[eToro](/wiki/EToro "EToro") CEO Yoni Assia on the [Colored
Coins](/wiki/Colored_Coins "Colored Coins") project and drafted its white
paper outlining additional use cases for blockchain technology.[16] However,
after failing to gain agreement on how the project should proceed, he proposed
the development of a new platform with a more robust scripting language—a
[Turing-complete](/wiki/Turing-complete "Turing-complete") programming
language[17]—that would eventually become Ethereum.[14]

Ethereum was announced at the North American Bitcoin Conference in Miami, in
January 2014.

[18] During the conference, [Gavin Wood](/wiki/Gavin_Wood "Gavin
Wood"), [Charles Hoskinson](/wiki/Charles_Hoskinson "Charles Hoskinson"), and
[Anthony Di Iorio](/wiki/Anthony_Di_Iorio "Anthony Di Iorio") (who financed
the project) rented a house in Miami with Buterin at which they could develop
a fuller sense of what Ethereum might become.[18] Di Iorio invited friend
[Joseph Lubin](/wiki/Joseph_Lubin_\(entrepreneur\) "Joseph Lubin
\(entrepreneur\)"), who invited reporter Morgen Peck, to bear witness.[18]
Peck subsequently wrote about the experience in
_[Wired](/wiki/Wired_\(magazine\) "Wired \(magazine\)")_.[19] Six months later
the founders met again in [Zug](/wiki/Zug "Zug"), Switzerland, where Buterin
told the founders that the project would proceed as a non-profit.

Hoskinson
left the project at that time and soon after founded IOHK, a blockchain
company responsible for [Cardano](/wiki/Cardano_\(blockchain_platform\)
"Cardano \(blockchain platform\)").[18]

Ethereum has an unusually long list of founders.[20] Anthony Di Iorio wrote:
"Ethereum was founded by Vitalik Buterin, Myself, Charles Hoskinson, Mihai
Alisie & Amir Chetrit (the initial 5) in December 2013. Joseph Lubin, Gavin
Wood, & Jeffrey Wilcke were added in early 2014 as founders." Buterin chose
the name Ethereum after browsing [a list of elements from science
fiction](/wiki/List_of_fictional_elements,_materials,_isotopes_and_subatomic_particles
"List of fictional elements, materials, isotopes and subatomic particles") on
[Wikipedia](/wiki/Wikipedia "Wikipedia").

He stated, "I immediately realized
that I liked it better than all of the other alternatives that I had seen; I
suppose it was that [it] sounded nice and it had the word
'[ether](/wiki/Luminiferous_aether "Luminiferous aether")', referring to the
hypothetical invisible medium that permeates the universe and allows light to
travel."[18] Buterin wanted his platform to be the underlying and
imperceptible medium for the applications running on top of it.[21]

### Development (2014)

Formal development of the software underlying Ethereum began in early 2014
through a Swiss company, Ethereum Switzerland GmbH (_EthSuisse_).[22] The idea
of putting executable [smart contracts](/wiki/Smart_contract "Smart contract")
in the blockchain needed to be specified before it could be implemented in
software. This work was done by Gavin Wood, then the [chief technology
officer](/wiki/Chief_technology_officer "Chief technology officer"), in the
Ethereum Yellow Paper that specified the Ethereum Virtual Machine.

[23][24]
Subsequently, a Swiss non-profit foundation, the **Ethereum Foundation**
(_Stiftung Ethereum_), was founded. Development was funded by an online public
crowd sale from July to August 2014, in which participants bought the Ethereum
value token (ether) with another digital currency, [bitcoin](/wiki/Bitcoin
"Bitcoin"). While there was early praise for the technical innovations of
Ethereum, questions were also raised about its security and scalability.[12]

### Launch and the DAO event (2014–2016)

Several codenamed prototypes of Ethereum were developed over 18 months in 2014
and 2015 by the Ethereum Foundation as part of their [proof-of-
concept](/wiki/Proof_of_concept#Software_development "Proof of concept")
series.[4] "Olympic" was the last prototype and public beta pre-release. The
Olympic network gave users a [bug bounty](/wiki/Bug_bounty "Bug bounty") of
25,000 ether for stress-testing the Ethereum blockchain.

On 30 July 2015,
"Frontier" marked the official launch of the Ethereum platform, and Ethereum
created its "genesis block".[4][25] The genesis block contained 8,893
transactions allocating various amounts of ether to different addresses, and a
block reward of 5 ETH.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Since the initial launch, Ethereum has undergone a number of planned protocol
upgrades, which are important changes affecting the underlying functionality
and/or [incentive structures](/wiki/Incentive_compatibility "Incentive
compatibility") of the platform.[26][27] Protocol upgrades are accomplished by
means of a [hard fork](/wiki/Hard_fork "Hard fork").

[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In 2016, a [decentralized autonomous
organization](/wiki/Decentralized_autonomous_organization "Decentralized
autonomous organization") called [The DAO](/wiki/The_DAO_\(organization\) "The
DAO \(organization\)")—a set of smart contracts developed on the
platform—raised a record US$150 million in a [crowd sale](/wiki/Token_sale
"Token sale") to fund the project.[28] The DAO was exploited in June 2016 when
US$50 million of DAO tokens were stolen by an unknown hacker.[29][30] The
event sparked a debate in the crypto-community about whether Ethereum should
perform a contentious "hard fork" to reappropriate the affected funds.[31] The
fork resulted in the network splitting into two blockchains: Ethereum with the
theft reversed, and [Ethereum Classic](/wiki/Ethereum_Classic "Ethereum
Classic") which continued on the original chain.

[32]

### Continued development and milestones (2017–present)

In March 2017, various [blockchain](/wiki/Blockchain "Blockchain") startups,
research groups, and [_Fortune_ 500](/wiki/Fortune_500 "Fortune 500")
companies announced the creation of the Enterprise Ethereum Alliance (EEA)
with 30 founding members.[33] By May 2017, the nonprofit organization had 116
enterprise members, including [ConsenSys](/wiki/ConsenSys "ConsenSys"), [CME
Group](/wiki/CME_Group "CME Group"), [Cornell University's research
group](/wiki/Cornell_University#Research "Cornell University"), [Toyota
Research Institute](/wiki/Toyota_Group "Toyota Group"), [Samsung
SDS](/wiki/Samsung_SDS "Samsung SDS"), [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft
"Microsoft"), [Intel](/wiki/Intel "Intel"), [J. P.
Morgan](/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase "JPMorgan Chase"), [Cooley LLP](/wiki/Cooley_LLP
"Cooley LLP"),

[Merck KGaA](/wiki/Merck_KGaA "Merck KGaA"),
[DTCC](/wiki/Depository_Trust_%26_Clearing_Corporation "Depository Trust &
Clearing Corporation"), [Deloitte](/wiki/Deloitte "Deloitte"),
[Accenture](/wiki/Accenture "Accenture"), [Banco
Santander](/wiki/Banco_Santander "Banco Santander"), [BNY
Mellon](/wiki/BNY_Mellon "BNY Mellon"), [ING](/wiki/ING_Group "ING Group"),
and [National Bank of Canada](/wiki/National_Bank_of_Canada "National Bank of
Canada").[34][35] By July 2017, there were over 150 members in the alliance,
including [MasterCard](/wiki/MasterCard "MasterCard"), [Cisco
Systems](/wiki/Cisco_Systems "Cisco Systems"), [Sberbank](/wiki/Sberbank
"Sberbank"), and [Scotiabank](/wiki/Scotiabank "Scotiabank").

[36]

#### _CryptoKitties_ and the ERC-721 NFT standard

In 2017, _[CryptoKitties](/wiki/CryptoKitties "CryptoKitties")_ , the
[blockchain game](/wiki/Blockchain_game "Blockchain game") and [decentralized
application](/wiki/Decentralized_application "Decentralized application")
(dApp) featuring digital cat artwork as [NFTs](/wiki/Non-fungible_token "Non-
fungible token"), was launched on the Ethereum network.[37] In cultivating
popularity with users and collectors, it gained notable mainstream media
attention providing significant exposure to Ethereum in the process.[38] It
was considered the most popular smart contract in use on the network[39] but
it also highlighted concerns over Ethereum's scalability due to the game's
substantial consumption of network capacity at the time.

[40]

In January 2018, a community-driven paper (an EIP, "Ethereum Improvement
Proposal") under the leadership of [civic hacker](/wiki/Hacker#Civic_hacker
"Hacker") and lead author [William Entriken](/wiki/William_Entriken "William
Entriken") was published, called _ERC-721: Non-Fungible Token Standard._[41]
It introduced [ERC-721](/wiki/ERC-721 "ERC-721"), the first official NFT
standard on Ethereum.[42] This standardization allowed Ethereum to become
central to a multi-billion dollar digital collectibles market.[43]

#### Continued developments

By January 2018, ether was the second-largest cryptocurrency in terms of
market capitalization, behind bitcoin.[44] As of
2021[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethereum&action=edit),
it maintained that relative position.[2][3]

In 2019, Ethereum Foundation employee [Virgil Griffith](/wiki/Virgil_Griffith
"Virgil Griffith") was arrested by the US government for presenting at a
blockchain conference in North Korea.

[45] He would later plead guilty to one
count of conspiring to violate the International Emergency Economic Powers Act
in 2021.[46]

In March 2021, [Visa Inc.](/wiki/Visa_Inc. "Visa Inc.") announced that it
began settling [stablecoin](/wiki/Stablecoin "Stablecoin") transactions using
Ethereum.[47] In April 2021, [JP Morgan Chase](/wiki/JP_Morgan_Chase "JP
Morgan Chase"), [UBS](/wiki/UBS "UBS"), and [MasterCard](/wiki/MasterCard
"MasterCard") announced that they were investing US$65 million into
[ConsenSys](/wiki/ConsenSys "ConsenSys"), a software development firm that
builds Ethereum-related infrastructure.[48]

There were two network upgrades in 2021. The first was "Berlin", implemented
on 14 April 2021.[49] The second was "London", which took effect on 5
August.

[50] The London upgrade included Ethereum Improvement Proposal ("EIP")
1559, a mechanism for reducing transaction fee
[volatility](/wiki/Volatility_\(finance\) "Volatility \(finance\)"). The
mechanism causes a portion of the ether paid in transaction fees for each
block to be destroyed rather than given to the block proposer, reducing the
inflation rate of ether and potentially resulting in periods of deflation.[51]

On 27 August 2021, the blockchain experienced a brief
[fork](/wiki/Fork_\(blockchain\) "Fork \(blockchain\)") that was the result of
clients running different incompatible software versions.[52]

### Ethereum 2.0

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Ethereum_Merge_Party_in_San_Francisco_in_2022.jpg/220px-
Ethereum_Merge_Party_in_San_Francisco_in_2022.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ethereum_Merge_Party_in_San_Francisco_in_2022.jpg)Ethereum
enthusiasts gather for a Merge party in San Francisco in 2022.

Ethereum 2.0 (Eth2) was a set of three or more upgrades, also known as
"phases", meant to transition the network's consensus mechanism to proof-of-
stake, and to scale the network's transaction throughput with execution
sharding and an improved EVM architecture.[53][_[non-primary source
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources
"Wikipedia:No original research")_]

The switch from proof-of-work to proof-of-stake on 15 September 2022 has cut
Ethereum's energy usage by 99%. This upgrade, known as "The Merge", was the
first phase in the series of upgrades. However, the impact this has on [global
energy consumption](/wiki/Global_energy_consumption "Global energy
consumption") and climate change may be limited since the computers previously
used for mining ether may be used to mine other cryptocurrencies that are
energy-intensive.[10]

On March 13, 2024 the second phase known as "Dencun" or also "Deneb-Cancun"
upgrade went live.

This upgrade lowered the transaction fees on the many Layer
2 networks built on top of the base Ethereum blockchain.[54]

## Design

### Overview

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-
new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)|
This section **relies excessively on[references](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability
"Wikipedia:Verifiability") to [primary
sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources
"Wikipedia:No original research")**. Please improve this section by adding
[secondary or tertiary
sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources
"Wikipedia:No original research").

_( May 2024)__([Learn how and when to
remove this message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance
template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
Ethereum is a [peer-to-peer network](/wiki/Peer-to-peer_network "Peer-to-peer
network") that maintains a [database](/wiki/Database "Database") containing
the storage values of all Ethereum accounts and processes state-altering
transactions.[55] Approximately every 12 seconds, a batch of new transactions,
known as a "block", is processed by the network. Each block contains a
[cryptographic hash](/wiki/Cryptographic_hash_function "Cryptographic hash
function") identifying the series of blocks that must precede it if the block
is to be considered valid. This series of blocks is known as the
[blockchain](/wiki/Blockchain "Blockchain").[56]

Each "node" (network participant) connects with a relatively small subset of
the network to offer blocks and unvalidated transactions (i.e. transactions
not yet in the blockchain) to its peers for download, and it downloads any of
these from its peers that it doesn't already have.

Each node usually has a
unique set of peers, so that offering an item to its peers results in the
propagation of that item throughout the entire network within seconds. A
node's collection of unvalidated transactions is known as its "mempool".[57]

A node may choose to create a copy of the state for itself. It does this by
starting with the genesis state and executing every transaction in the
blockchain, in the proper order of blocks and in the order they are listed
within each block.[58]

Any Ethereum account may "stake" (deposit) 32 ETH to become a validator. At
the end of each "epoch" (32 block slots, each slot lasting 12 seconds), each
validator is [pseudorandomly](/wiki/Pseudorandomness "Pseudorandomness")
assigned to one of the slots of the epoch after the next, either as the block
proposer or as an attester.

During a slot, the block proposer uses their
mempool to create a block that is intended to become the new "head" (latest
block) of the blockchain, and the attesters attest to which block is at the
head of the chain. If a validator makes self-contradicting proposals or
attestations, or if it is inactive, it loses a portion of its stake. It may
add to its stake at any time. A validator's attestation is given a weight
equal to its stake or 32, whichever is less. According to the Ethereum
protocol, the blockchain with the highest accumulated weight of attestations
at any given time is to be regarded as the canonical chain. Validators are
rewarded for making valid proposals and attestations. A validator's rewards
are paid via transactions within the same chain that contains their proposal
or attestation, and therefore would have little or no market value unless that
chain becomes the canonical chain. This incentivizes validators to support the
chain that they think other validators view as the canonical chain, which
results in a high degree of consensus.

[59]

### Ether

Ether (ETH) is the cryptocurrency generated in accordance with the Ethereum
protocol as a reward to validators in a [proof-of-stake](/wiki/Proof_of_stake
"Proof of stake") system for adding blocks to the blockchain. Ether is
represented in the state as an [unsigned](/wiki/Signedness "Signedness")
[integer](/wiki/Integer_\(computer_science\) "Integer \(computer science\)")
associated with each account, this being the account's ETH balance denominated
in wei (1018 wei = 1 ether). At the end of each epoch, new ETH is generated by
the addition of protocol-specified amounts to the balances of all validators
for that epoch, with the block proposers receiving the largest portion.
Additionally, ether is the only currency accepted by the protocol as payment
for the transaction fee. The transaction fee is composed of two parts: the
base fee and the tip. The base fee is "burned" (deleted from existence) and
the tip goes to the block proposer. The validator reward together with the
tips provide the incentive to validators to keep the blockchain growing (i.e.

to keep processing new transactions). Therefore, ETH is fundamental to the
operation of the network. Ether may be "sent" from one account to another via
a transaction, the execution of which simply entails subtracting the _amount
to be sent_ from the sender's balance and adding the same amount to the
recipient's balance.[60]

Ether is often erroneously referred to as "Ethereum".[61]

The uppercase Greek letter [Xi](/wiki/Xi_\(letter\) "Xi \(letter\)"), Ξ, is
sometimes used as a [currency symbol](/wiki/Currency_symbol "Currency symbol")
for ether.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Accounts

There are two types of accounts on Ethereum: user accounts (also known as
externally-owned accounts), and contract accounts. Both types have an ETH
balance, may transfer ETH to any account, may execute the code of another
contract, or create a new contract, and are identified on the blockchain and
in the state by an account address.

[62]

Contracts are the only type of account that has associated
[bytecode](/wiki/Bytecode "Bytecode") and storage (to store contract-specific
state). The code of a contract is evaluated when a transaction is sent to it.
The code of the contract may read user-specified data from the transaction,
and may have a [return value](/wiki/Return_statement "Return statement"). In
addition to [control flow](/wiki/Control_flow "Control flow") statements, the
bytecode may include instructions to send ETH, read from and write to the
contract's storage, create temporary storage ([memory](/wiki/Volatile_memory
"Volatile memory")) that vanishes at the end of code evaluation, perform
[arithmetic](/wiki/Arithmetic "Arithmetic") and hashing operations, send
transactions to other contracts (thus executing their code), create new
contracts, and query information about the current transaction or the
blockchain.[63][_[unreliable source?

](/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources
"Wikipedia:Reliable sources")_]

#### Addresses

Ethereum addresses are composed of the prefix "`0x`" (a common identifier for
[hexadecimal](/wiki/Hexadecimal "Hexadecimal")) concatenated with the
rightmost 20 bytes of the [Keccak-256](/wiki/SHA-3 "SHA-3") hash of the
[ECDSA](/wiki/Elliptic_Curve_Digital_Signature_Algorithm "Elliptic Curve
Digital Signature Algorithm") [public key](/wiki/Public-key_cryptography
"Public-key cryptography") (the curve used is the so-called _secp256k1_). In
hexadecimal, two digits represent a byte, and so addresses contain 40
hexadecimal digits after the "`0x`", e.g.
`0xb794f5ea0ba39494ce839613fffba74279579268`. Contract addresses are in the
same format, however, they are determined by sender and creation transaction
[nonce](/wiki/Cryptographic_nonce "Cryptographic nonce").

[24][_[non-primary
source
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources
"Wikipedia:No original research")_]

### Virtual machine

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Ethereum_Transactions_Chart.png/350px-
Ethereum_Transactions_Chart.png)](/wiki/File:Ethereum_Transactions_Chart.png)The
number of daily confirmed Ethereum transactions as of February 2024

The Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) is the
[runtime](/wiki/Runtime_\(program_lifecycle_phase\) "Runtime \(program
lifecycle phase\)") environment for transaction execution in Ethereum. The EVM
is a [stack](/wiki/Stack_\(abstract_data_type\) "Stack \(abstract data
type\)") based virtual machine with an [instruction
set](/wiki/Instruction_set_architecture "Instruction set architecture")
specifically designed for Ethereum. The instruction set includes, among other
things, stack operations, memory operations, and operations to inspect the
current execution context, such as remaining gas, information about the
current block, and the current transaction.

The EVM is designed to be
[deterministic](/wiki/Deterministic_algorithm "Deterministic algorithm") on a
wide variety of [hardware](/wiki/Computer_hardware "Computer hardware") and
[operating systems](/wiki/Operating_system "Operating system"), so that given
a pre-transaction state and a transaction, each node produces the same post-
transaction state, thereby enabling network consensus. The formal definition
of the EVM is specified in the Ethereum Yellow Paper.

[24][64] EVMs have been
implemented in [C++](/wiki/C%2B%2B "C++"),
[C#](/wiki/C_Sharp_\(programming_language\) "C Sharp \(programming
language\)"), [Go](/wiki/Go_\(programming_language\) "Go \(programming
language\)"), [Haskell](/wiki/Haskell_\(programming_language\) "Haskell
\(programming language\)"), [Java](/wiki/Java_\(programming_language\) "Java
\(programming language\)"), [JavaScript](/wiki/JavaScript "JavaScript"),
[Python](/wiki/Python_\(programming_language\) "Python \(programming
language\)"), [Ruby](/wiki/Ruby_\(programming_language\) "Ruby \(programming
language\)"), [Rust](/wiki/Rust_\(programming_language\) "Rust \(programming
language\)"), [Elixir](/wiki/Elixir_\(programming_language\) "Elixir
\(programming language\)"), [Erlang](/wiki/Erlang_\(programming_language\)
"Erlang \(programming language\)"), and
soon[_[when?

](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_]
[WebAssembly](/wiki/WebAssembly "WebAssembly").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Gas

Gas is a [unit of account](/wiki/Unit_of_account "Unit of account") within the
EVM used in the calculation of the transaction fee, which is the amount of ETH
a transaction's sender must pay to the network to have the transaction
included in the blockchain. Each type of operation which may be performed by
the EVM is [hardcoded](/wiki/Hardcoded "Hardcoded") with a certain gas cost,
which is intended to be roughly
[proportional](/wiki/Proportionality_\(mathematics\) "Proportionality
\(mathematics\)") to the monetary value of the resources (e.g.
[computation](/wiki/Computation "Computation") and
[storage](/wiki/Computer_data_storage "Computer data storage")) a node must
expend or dedicate to perform that operation.

[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

When a sender is creating a transaction, the sender must specify a _gas limit_
and _gas price_. The _gas limit_ is the maximum amount of gas the sender is
willing to use in the transaction, and the _gas price_ is the amount of ETH
the sender wishes to pay to the network per unit of gas used. A transaction
may only be included in the blockchain at a block slot that has a _base gas
price_ less than or equal to the transaction's _gas price_. The portion of the
_gas price_ that is in excess of the _base gas price_ is known as the tip and
goes to the block proposer; the higher the tip, the more incentive a block
proposer has to include the transaction in their block, and thus the quicker
the transaction will be included in the blockchain. The sender buys the full
amount of gas (i.e.

their ETH balance is debited _gas limit_ × _gas price_ and
their gas balance is set to _gas limit_) up-front, at the start of the
execution of the transaction, and is refunded at the end for any unused gas.
If at any point the transaction does not have enough gas to perform the next
operation, the transaction is reverted but the sender is still only refunded
for the unused gas. In [user interfaces](/wiki/User_interface "User
interface"), gas prices are typically denominated in gigawei (Gwei), a subunit
of ETH equal to 10−9 ETH.[65]

## Applications

The EVM's [instruction set](/wiki/Instruction_set "Instruction set") is
[Turing-complete](/wiki/Turing_completeness "Turing completeness").[24]
Popular uses of Ethereum have included the creation of fungible (ERC-20) and
non-fungible (ERC-721) tokens with a variety of properties,
[crowdfunding](/wiki/Crowdfunding "Crowdfunding") (e.g.

[initial coin
offerings](/wiki/Initial_coin_offerings "Initial coin offerings")),
[decentralized finance](/wiki/Decentralized_finance "Decentralized finance"),
[decentralized exchanges](/wiki/Decentralized_exchange "Decentralized
exchange"), [decentralized autonomous
organizations](/wiki/Decentralized_autonomous_organization "Decentralized
autonomous organization") (DAOs), games, [prediction
markets](/wiki/Prediction_market "Prediction market"), and
gambling.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Contract source code

Ethereum's smart contracts are written in [high-level](/wiki/High-
level_programming_language "High-level programming language") programming
languages and then [compiled](/wiki/Compiler "Compiler") down to EVM
[bytecode](/wiki/Bytecode "Bytecode") and deployed to the Ethereum blockchain.

They can be written in [Solidity](/wiki/Solidity "Solidity") (a language
library with similarities to [C](/wiki/C_\(programming_language\) "C
\(programming language\)") and [JavaScript](/wiki/JavaScript "JavaScript")),
Serpent (similar to [Python](/wiki/Python_\(programming_language\) "Python
\(programming language\)"), but deprecated), Yul (an intermediate language
that can compile to various different backends—EVM 1.0, EVM 1.5, and eWASM are
planned), LLL (a [low-level](/wiki/Low-level_programming_language "Low-level
programming language") [Lisp](/wiki/Lisp_\(programming_language\) "Lisp
\(programming language\)")-like language), and Mutan
([Go](/wiki/Go_\(programming_language\) "Go \(programming language\)")-based,
but deprecated). Source code and compiler information are usually published
along with the launch of the contract so that users can see the code and
verify that it compiles to the bytecode that is on-chain.

[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

One issue related to using smart contracts on a public blockchain is that
bugs, including security holes, are visible to all but cannot be fixed
quickly.[66] One example of this is the 2016 attack on [The
DAO](/wiki/The_DAO_\(organization\) "The DAO \(organization\)"), which could
not be quickly stopped or reversed.[29]

### ERC-20 tokens

The ERC-20 (Ethereum Request-for-Comments #20) Token Standard allows for
[fungible](/wiki/Fungible "Fungible") tokens on the Ethereum
[blockchain](/wiki/Blockchain "Blockchain"). The standard, proposed by Fabian
Vogelsteller in November 2015, implements an [API](/wiki/API "API") for tokens
within [smart contracts](/wiki/Smart_contract "Smart contract"). The standard
provides functions that include the transfer of tokens from one account to
another, getting the current token balance of an account, and getting the
total supply of the token available on the network.

Smart contracts that
correctly implement ERC-20 processes are called ERC-20 Token Contracts, and
they keep track of created tokens on Ethereum. Numerous cryptocurrencies have
launched as ERC-20 tokens and have been distributed through [initial coin
offerings](/wiki/Initial_coin_offerings "Initial coin offerings").[67]

### Non-fungible tokens (NFTs)

Main article: [Non-fungible token](/wiki/Non-fungible_token "Non-fungible
token")

Ethereum also allows for the creation of unique and indivisible tokens, called
[non-fungible tokens](/wiki/Non-fungible_token "Non-fungible token")
(NFTs).[68] Since tokens of this type are unique, they have been used to
represent such things as collectibles, digital art, sports memorabilia,
virtual real estate, and items within games.

[69] ERC-721 is the first official
NFT standard for Ethereum and was followed up by ERC-1155 which introduced
semi-fungibility, both are widely used,[70] though some fully fungible tokens
using ERC-20 have been used for NFTs such as _[CryptoPunks](/wiki/CryptoPunks
"CryptoPunks")_.[71]

The first NFT project, Etheria, a 3D map of tradable and customizable
hexagonal tiles, was deployed to the network in October 2015 and demonstrated
live at DEVCON1 in November of that year.

[72] In 2021,
[Christie's](/wiki/Christie%27s "Christie's") sold a digital image with an NFT
by [Beeple](/wiki/Beeple "Beeple") for US$69.3 million, making him the [third-
most-valuable living
artist](/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_artworks_by_living_artists "List of most
expensive artworks by living artists") in terms of [auction](/wiki/Art_auction
"Art auction") prices at the time, although observers have noted that both the
buyer and seller had a vested interest in driving demand for the artist's
work.[73][74]

### Decentralized finance

Main article: [Decentralized finance](/wiki/Decentralized_finance
"Decentralized finance")

Decentralized finance (DeFi) offers [financial
instruments](/wiki/Financial_instrument "Financial instrument") in a
decentralized architecture, outside of companies' and governments' control,
such as money market funds which let users earn interest.

[75] DeFi
applications are typically accessed through a [Web3](/wiki/Web3
"Web3")-enabled browser extension or application, such as
[MetaMask](/wiki/MetaMask "MetaMask"), which allows users to directly interact
with the Ethereum blockchain through a website.[76] Many of these DApps can
connect and work together to create complex financial services.[77]

Examples of DeFi platforms include
[MakerDAO](/w/index.php?title=MakerDAO&action=edit&redlink=1 "MakerDAO \(page
does not exist\)").[78] [Uniswap](/wiki/Uniswap "Uniswap"), a [decentralized
exchange](/wiki/Decentralized_exchange "Decentralized exchange") for tokens on
Ethereum grew from US$20 million in liquidity to US$2.9 billion in 2020.[79]
As of October 2020, over US$11 billion was invested in various DeFi
protocols.

[80] Additionally, through a process called "wrapping", certain DeFi
protocols allow synthetic versions of various assets (such as bitcoin, gold,
and oil) to be tradeable on Ethereum and also compatible with all of
Ethereum's major wallets and applications.[80]

### Enterprise software

Ethereum-based software and networks, independent from the public Ethereum
chain, have been tested by [enterprise software](/wiki/Enterprise_software
"Enterprise software") companies.[81] Interested parties have included
[Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft"), [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM"), [JPMorgan
Chase](/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase "JPMorgan Chase"),[60] [Deloitte](/wiki/Deloitte
"Deloitte"), R3, and [Innovate UK](/wiki/Innovate_UK "Innovate UK") (cross-
border payments prototype).

[82] [Barclays](/wiki/Barclays "Barclays"),
[UBS](/wiki/UBS "UBS"), [Credit Suisse](/wiki/Credit_Suisse "Credit Suisse"),
[Amazon](/wiki/Amazon_\(company\) "Amazon \(company\)"),
[Visa](/wiki/Visa_Inc. "Visa Inc."), and other companies have also
experimented with Ethereum.[83][84]

### Permissioned ledgers

Ethereum-based [permissioned
blockchain](/wiki/Blockchain_\(database\)#Openness "Blockchain \(database\)")
variants are used and being investigated for various projects:

  * In 2017, [JPMorgan Chase](/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase "JPMorgan Chase") proposed developing [JPM Coin](/wiki/JPM_Coin "JPM Coin") on a permissioned-variant of Ethereum blockchain dubbed "Quorum".[85] It is "designed to toe the line between private and public in the realm of shuffling derivatives and payments.

The idea is to satisfy regulators who need seamless access to financial goings-on while protecting the privacy of parties that don't wish to reveal their identities nor the details of their transactions to the general public."[86]

### Performance

As of January
2016[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethereum&action=edit),
the Ethereum protocol could process about 25 transactions per second; this did
not change after the move to proof-of-stake. In comparison, the
[Visa](/wiki/Visa_Inc. "Visa Inc.") payment platform processes 45,000 payments
per second. This has led some to question the scalability of Ethereum.[87]

A proposal to partition global state and computation into [shard
chains](/wiki/Shard_\(database_architecture\) "Shard \(database
architecture\)") was presented at Ethereum's Devcon 3 in November 2017.[88] If
implemented, each node in the network would only have to store and validate a
subset of the network.

Ethereum's blockchain uses a [Merkle](/wiki/Merkle_tree "Merkle
tree")-Patricia Tree to store account state in each block.[89] The trie allows
for storage savings, set membership proofs (called "Merkle proofs"), and light
client synchronization. The network has faced congestion problems, such as in
2017 in relation to _[CryptoKitties](/wiki/CryptoKitties
"CryptoKitties")_.[90]

## Regulation

See also: [2020s commodities boom](/wiki/2020s_commodities_boom "2020s
commodities boom")

In the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"), the proposed
[Digital Commodities Consumer Protection
Act](/wiki/Digital_Commodities_Consumer_Protection_Act "Digital Commodities
Consumer Protection Act") would treat Ethereum and other cryptocurrencies as
[commodities](/wiki/Commodity "Commodity"), which could then be regulated by
the [Commodity Futures Trading
Commission](/wiki/Commodity_Futures_Trading_Commission "Commodity Futures
Trading Commission") (CFTC).

[91][92]

**Dogecoin** ([/ˈdoʊ(d)ʒkɔɪn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")
[_DOHJ -koyn_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation
respelling key") or [_DOHZH -koyn_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key
"Help:Pronunciation respelling key"),[2]
[Abbreviation](/wiki/ISO_4217#Cryptocurrencies "ISO 4217"): **DOGE** ;
[sign](/wiki/Currency_symbol "Currency symbol"): **Ð**) is a
[cryptocurrency](/wiki/Cryptocurrency "Cryptocurrency") created by software
engineers Billy Markus and Jackson Palmer, who decided to create a payment
system as a joke, making fun of the wild speculation in cryptocurrencies at
the time.

[3] It is considered both the first "[meme coin](/wiki/Meme_coin
"Meme coin")", and more specifically the first "dog coin". Despite its
satirical nature, some consider it a legitimate investment prospect. Dogecoin
features the face of [Kabosu](/wiki/Kabosu_\(dog\) "Kabosu \(dog\)") from the
"[doge](/wiki/Doge_\(meme\) "Doge \(meme\)")" [meme](/wiki/Internet_meme
"Internet meme") as its logo and namesake.[4][5][6] It was introduced on
December 6, 2013, and quickly developed its own [online
community](/wiki/Online_community "Online community"), reaching a peak market
capitalization of over US$85 billion[a] on May 5, 2021.[7] As of 2021, it is
the [sleeve sponsor](/wiki/Shirt_sponsor "Shirt sponsor")[b] of [Watford
Football Club](/wiki/Watford_Football_Club "Watford Football Club").

[8]

Dogecoin.com promotes the currency as the "fun and friendly Internet
currency", referencing its origins as a "joke".[9] Software engineers Billy
Markus and Jackson Palmer launched the satirical cryptocurrency as a way to
make fun of [Bitcoin](/wiki/Bitcoin "Bitcoin") and the many other
cryptocurrencies boasting grand plans to take over the world. With the help of
[Reddit](/wiki/Reddit "Reddit"), the site became an instant hit. Within two
weeks, Dogecoin had established a dedicated blog and forum, and its market
value reached $8 million, once jumping to become the seventh largest
electronic currency in the world.[10]

## History

Originally formed as a "joke",[11] Dogecoin was created by [IBM](/wiki/IBM
"IBM") software engineer Billy Markus and [Adobe](/wiki/Adobe_Inc. "Adobe
Inc.") software engineer Jackson Palmer. They wanted to create a peer-to-peer
digital currency that could reach a broader demographic than
[Bitcoin](/wiki/Bitcoin "Bitcoin"). In addition, they wanted to distance it
from the controversial history of other coins.

[12] Dogecoin was officially
launched on December 6, 2013, and within the first 30 days, there were over a
million visitors to Dogecoin.com.[13]

Palmer is credited with making the idea a reality. At the time, he was a
member of the Adobe marketing department in [Sydney](/wiki/Sydney,_Australia
"Sydney, Australia"), Australia.[14] Palmer had purchased the domain
Dogecoin.com and added a [splash screen](/wiki/Splash_screen "Splash screen"),
which featured the coin's logo and scattered [Comic Sans](/wiki/Comic_Sans
"Comic Sans") text. Markus reached out to Palmer after seeing the site, and
started efforts to develop the currency. Markus designed Dogecoin's protocol
based on existing cryptocurrencies Luckycoin and [Litecoin](/wiki/Litecoin
"Litecoin"),[15] which use [scrypt](/wiki/Scrypt "Scrypt") technology in their
[proof-of-work](/wiki/Proof-of-work "Proof-of-work") algorithm.

[16] The use of
scrypt means that miners cannot use [SHA-256](/wiki/SHA-2 "SHA-2") bitcoin
mining equipment, and instead must use dedicated [field-programmable gate
array](/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array "Field-programmable gate array")
and [application-specific integrated circuit](/wiki/Application-
specific_integrated_circuit "Application-specific integrated circuit") devices
for mining which are known to be more complex to produce.[17][18]

On December 19, 2013, Dogecoin jumped nearly 300% in value in 72 hours, rising
from $0.00026 to $0.00095,[19] with a volume of billions of Dogecoins traded
per day. This growth occurred during a time when Bitcoin and many other
cryptocurrencies were reeling from China's decision to forbid Chinese banks
from investing in the Bitcoin economy.

[15] Three days later, Dogecoin
experienced its first major crash when its price dropped by 80% due to this
event and to large [mining pools](/wiki/Mining_pool "Mining pool") exploiting
the small amount of computing power required at the time to mine Dogecoin.[20]

On December 25, 2013, the first major theft of Dogecoin occurred when millions
of coins were stolen during a [hack](/wiki/Hack_\(computer_security\) "Hack
\(computer security\)") on the online [cryptocurrency
wallet](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_wallet "Cryptocurrency wallet") platform
Dogewallet.[21] The hacker gained access to the platform's filesystem and
modified its send/receive page to send any and all coins to a static [internet
protocol address](/wiki/Internet_protocol_address "Internet protocol
address").[22][23] This hacking incident spiked tweets about Dogecoin, making
it the most mentioned altcoin on [Twitter](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter") at the
time, although it was in reference to a negative event.

To help those who lost
funds on Dogewallet after its breach, the Dogecoin community started an
initiative named "SaveDogemas" to help donate coins to those who had them
stolen. Approximately one month later, enough money was donated to cover all
of the coins that were stolen.[24]

In January 2014, the trading volume of Dogecoin briefly surpassed that of all
other cryptocurrencies combined. However, its market capitalization remained
substantially behind that of Bitcoin. Initially, Dogecoin featured a
randomized reward that is received for each mining block. However, in March
2014, this behaviour was updated to a static block reward.[25] Co-founder
Jackson Palmer left the cryptocurrency community in 2015 and has no plans to
return, having come to the belief that cryptocurrency, originally conceived as
a libertarian alternative to money, is fundamentally exploitative and built to
enrich its top proponents. His co-founder, Billy Markus, agreed that Palmer's
position was generally valid.

[26][27]

During the 2017 to early 2018 [cryptocurrency
bubble](/wiki/Cryptocurrency_bubble "Cryptocurrency bubble"), Dogecoin briefly
reached a peak of $0.017 on January 7, 2018, putting its total market
capitalization near $2 billion.

In July 2020, the price of Dogecoin spiked following a [TikTok](/wiki/TikTok
"TikTok") trend aimed at getting Dogecoin to $1.[28]

On May 9, 2021, [SpaceX](/wiki/SpaceX "SpaceX") announced a rideshare mission
to the Moon completely funded by Dogecoin, thus becoming the first space
mission funded by a cryptocurrency. Elon Musk confirmed this news via
Twitter.

[29] [DOGE-1](/wiki/Doge-1 "Doge-1"), a [CubeSat](/wiki/CubeSat
"CubeSat"), was planned to be a minor 40 kg rideshare payload on [Intuitive
Machines](/wiki/Intuitive_Machines "Intuitive Machines")' [IM-1](/wiki/IM-1
"IM-1") mission in Q1 2022,[30][31][32][33][34] but ultimately was delayed to
a potential later mission.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

On August 14, 2021, the Dogecoin Foundation announced the "re-establishment of
the Dogecoin Foundation (est 2014), with a renewed focus on supporting the
Dogecoin Ecosystem, Community and promoting the future of the Dogecoin
[Blockchain](/wiki/Blockchain "Blockchain").

"[35] The Foundation was
reinvigorated by the addition to its Board of notable advisors such as
[Vitalik Buterin](/wiki/Vitalik_Buterin "Vitalik Buterin")
([Ethereum](/wiki/Ethereum "Ethereum") co-founder and inventor) and [Jared
Birchall](/wiki/Jared_Birchall "Jared Birchall") (representing Elon
Musk).[36][37][38]

### 2021 boom and subsequent fall

In January 2021, Dogecoin went up over 800% in 24 hours, reaching $0.07, as a
result of attention from [Reddit](/wiki/Reddit "Reddit") users, partially
encouraged by [Elon Musk](/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk") and the [GameStop short
squeeze](/wiki/GameStop_short_squeeze "GameStop short squeeze").

[39] In
February 2021, Dogecoin hit a new high price of $0.08 following Twitter
encouragement from Musk, [Snoop Dogg](/wiki/Snoop_Dogg "Snoop Dogg") and [Gene
Simmons](/wiki/Gene_Simmons "Gene Simmons").[40] In March 2021, [Dallas
Mavericks](/wiki/Dallas_Mavericks "Dallas Mavericks") owner [Mark
Cuban](/wiki/Mark_Cuban "Mark Cuban") announced his [NBA](/wiki/NBA "NBA")
team would allow purchasing tickets and products with Dogecoin; within two
days, Cuban had declared his franchise had become the top Dogecoin merchant,
having carried out 20,000 transactions.[41]

In April 2021, Dogecoin and other cryptocurrencies surged, stimulated in part
by the [direct listing](/wiki/Direct_listing "Direct listing") for
cryptocurrency exchange [Coinbase](/wiki/Coinbase "Coinbase") on April 14,
although that platform did not provide trading of Dogecoin.

[42] Dogecoin first
reached $0.10 on April 14,[43] before hitting a new high of $0.45 on April 16
(up 400% that week[44]), with a volume of nearly $70 billion traded in the
preceding 24 hours.[45] At the
time[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dogecoin&action=edit),
Dogecoin's market capitalization approached $50 billion, making it the fifth-
highest-valued cryptocurrency;[46] its value had increased more than 7,000%
year-to-date.[45] Interest in Dogecoin contributed to an outage in electronic
trading platform [Robinhood](/wiki/Robinhood_\(company\) "Robinhood
\(company\)")'s cryptocurrency system on April 15, caused by "unprecedented
demand", and prompted concerns from experts of a nearing [speculative
bubble](/wiki/Speculative_bubble "Speculative bubble") in the cryptocurrency
market.[44]

On May 4, 2021, the value of Dogecoin first surpassed the symbolic hurdle of
$0.50.

[47]

In April 2023, a Dogecoin increase was attributed to Elon Musk temporarily
changing the logo on the Twitter app to a Doge logo.[48] In June 2023, Musk
was accused of insider trading by investors based on a series of stunts
including the change of logo.[49]

## Use and exchanges

Dogecoin is an altcoin[c] with a large userbase, and is traded against both
[fiat currencies](/wiki/Fiat_currencies "Fiat currencies") and other
cryptocurrencies on several reputable [cryptocurrency](/wiki/Cryptocurrency
"Cryptocurrency") exchanges and retail investment platforms.

Trading physical, tangible items in exchange for Dogecoin takes place on
online communities such as Reddit and Twitter, where users in such circles
frequently share cryptocurrency-related information.[5][50][51]

Several cases of people using their employers' or universities' computers to
mine Dogecoin have been discovered.[52][53]

Dogecoin has been used in an attempted property sale,[54] and it has been used
in the pornography[55] and gambling[d] industries.

### Online tipping

One major mainstream commercial application of the cryptocurrency has been
Internet-based tipping systems, in which social media users tip other users
for providing interesting or noteworthy content.[56]

#### Dogetipbot

Dogetipbot was a cryptocurrency transaction service used on popular sites like
Reddit and [Twitch](/wiki/Twitch_\(service\) "Twitch \(service\)"). It allowed
users to send Dogecoins to other users through commands via Reddit comments.
In May 2017, Dogetipbot was discontinued and taken offline after its creator
declared bankruptcy; this left many Dogetipbot users losing their coins stored
in the Dogetipbot system.[57]

## Smart contracts

Dogecoin's blockchain cannot interact with [smart
contracts](/wiki/Smart_contract "Smart contract") directly. Dogecoin can be
tied to the Ethereum blockchain in order to access some [decentralized
finance](/wiki/Decentralized_finance "Decentralized finance") (DeFi)
instruments.

[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Currency supply

Dogecoin started with a supply limit of Ð100 [billion](/wiki/Billion
"Billion"), which would have been far more coins than the top digital
currencies were then allowing. By mid-2015, the 100 billionth Dogecoin had
been mined, with an additional Ð5 billion put into circulation every year
thereafter. In February 2014, Palmer announced that the limit would be removed
in an effort to create a consistent reduction of its inflation rate over
time.[58]

## Mining parameters

Dogecoin's implementation differs from its predecessors: It was originally
[forked](/wiki/Fork_\(blockchain\) "Fork \(blockchain\)") from
[Litecoin](/wiki/Litecoin "Litecoin"), then refactored to Bitcoin. Dogecoin's
target block time is 1 minute, as opposed to Litecoin's 2.5 minutes and
Bitcoin's 10 minutes.

[5]

## Fundraising

### 2014 Winter Olympics

The Dogecoin community and foundation have encouraged fundraising for
charities and other notable causes. On January 19, 2014, a fundraiser was
established by the Dogecoin community to raise $50,000 for the [Jamaican
Bobsled Team](/wiki/Jamaican_Bobsled_Team "Jamaican Bobsled Team"), which had
qualified for, but could not afford to go to, the [Sochi Winter
Olympics](/wiki/Sochi_Winter_Olympics "Sochi Winter Olympics"). By the second
day, $36,000 worth of Dogecoin was donated and the Dogecoin to Bitcoin
exchange rate rose by 50%.[59] The Dogecoin community also raised funds for a
second Sochi athlete, [Shiva Keshavan](/wiki/Shiva_Keshavan "Shiva
Keshavan").

[60]

### Doge4Water

In 2014, The Dogecoin Foundation, led by [Eric Nakagawa](/wiki/Eric_Nakagawa
"Eric Nakagawa"), began collecting donations to build a well in the Tana river
basin in Kenya for [World Water Day](/wiki/World_Water_Day "World Water Day")
(March 22). The campaign, in cooperation with [Charity:
Water](/wiki/Charity:_Water "Charity: Water"), collected donations from more
than 4,000 donors, including one anonymous benefactor who donated 14,000,000
dogecoin (worth approximately $11,000 at the time), raising over
US$30,000.[61]

### NASCAR

On March 25, 2014, the Dogecoin community successfully raised Ð67.8 million

"NASCAR") [Sprint Cup Series](/wiki/Sprint_Cup_Series "Sprint Cup Series")
driver [Josh Wise](/wiki/Josh_Wise "Josh Wise"). Nicknamed the

98 car featured a Dogecoin/Reddit-sponsored paint
scheme and was driven by Wise at the [Aaron's 499](/wiki/2014_Aaron%27s_499
"2014 Aaron's 499") at [Talladega Superspeedway](/wiki/Talladega_Superspeedway
"Talladega Superspeedway").[63] Wise and the car were featured for nearly a
minute, during which the race commentators discussed Dogecoin and the
crowdfunding effort, while finishing twentieth and narrowly avoiding multiple
wrecks.[64]

[65][66] [Eutechnyx](/wiki/Eutechnyx "Eutechnyx"), the developer of

On March 2, 2021, [NASCAR Xfinity Series](/wiki/NASCAR_Xfinity_Series "NASCAR

99 car in the [Alsco
Uniforms 300](/wiki/NASCAR_Xfinity_Series_at_Las_Vegas_\(spring_race\) "NASCAR

## Criticism

Dogecoin's origin as a "joke", which makes it the first [meme
coin](/wiki/Meme_coin "Meme coin"), has made it difficult to be taken
seriously by mainstream media and financial experts.[69][70] The
cryptocurrency has had a long and problematic history of scams.[71][72][73]
Similar to many other cryptocurrencies, Dogecoin has been described by some
commentators as a form of [Ponzi](/wiki/Ponzi_scheme "Ponzi scheme") scheme.

Critics allege that Dogecoin investors who purchased Dogecoins early on, have
a large financial incentive to draw others into purchasing more Dogecoins in
order to drive the price up, therefore benefitting the early investors
financially at the direct expense of later purchasers.[74] This is primarily
because Dogecoin does not have a supply cap like other cryptocurrencies such
as Bitcoin, which has a capped supply of 21 million coins.[75]

## Elon Musk and Dogecoin

[Elon Musk](/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk") frequently uses his [X](/wiki/Twitter
"Twitter") platform to express his views on Dogecoin, which has led some to
claim that his actions amount to [market
manipulation](/wiki/Market_manipulation "Market manipulation")[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] because
the price of Dogecoin frequently experiences price movements shortly after his
tweets. Nevertheless, because cryptocurrencies are not regulated like stocks,
these actions are not illegal.

[76] Musk and his promotion of Dogecoin have
been criticized by Dogecoin co-founder Jackson Palmer, who called Musk a
"self-absorbed [grifter](/wiki/Confidence_trick "Confidence trick")".[77]

Musk's first Dogecoin-related tweet occurred on December 20, 2020. Musk
tweeted "One Word: Doge". Shortly after, the value of Dogecoin rose by
20%.[78] This was followed by a series of Dogecoin-related tweets by Musk in
early February 2021 captioned "Dogecoin is the people's crypto" and "no highs,
no lows, only Doge". Following these tweets, the value of Dogecoin rose by
roughly 40%.

[78]

On April 15, 2021, the price of Dogecoin rose by more than 100% after Musk
tweeted an image of [Joan Miró](/wiki/Joan_Mir%C3%B3 "Joan Miró")'s [_Dog
Barking at the Moon_ painting](/wiki/Dog_Barking_at_the_Moon_\(Mir%C3%B3\)
"Dog Barking at the Moon \(Miró\)") captioned "Doge Barking at the Moon",[79]
a message which was taken by some as a reference to the industry slang term
"to the moon",[80] meaning a hoped-for increase in a cryptocurrency's
value.[81]

On May 8, 2021, Dogecoin fell as much as 29.5%, dropping to US$0.49 during
Musk’s _[Saturday Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live "Saturday Night
Live")_ appearance.[82] It then rose by 11% on May 20, 2021, shortly after
Musk tweeted a Doge-related [meme](/wiki/Meme "Meme").

[83] In the same month,
the price of Dogecoin was up 10% in the hours after Musk tweeted a Reddit link
for users to submit proposals to improve the cryptocurrency.[84]

On December 14, 2021, Dogecoin spiked more than 20% after Musk said that
[Tesla](/wiki/Tesla,_Inc. "Tesla, Inc.") will accept the currency as a means
of payment for Tesla merchandise.[85][86]

On June 16, 2022, Elon Musk was named in a complaint seeking damages of $258
billion. The complaint was filed in federal court in Manhattan by plaintiff
Keith Johnson. Johnson cited Musk's repeated use of his massive social
influence to promote the [altcoin](/wiki/Altcoin "Altcoin"), which he claims
artificially inflated the price.[87]

It was reported in 2013 that Musk thinks Dogecoin could be used for Twitter
transactions.

[88] On October 27, 2022, Elon Musk completed [a deal to take
Twitter private](/wiki/Acquisition_of_Twitter_by_Elon_Musk "Acquisition of
Twitter by Elon Musk"). This led to a sustained rise in Dogecoin from October
25 to October 29, with Dogecoin increasing as much as 46%.[89]

Between April 3 and April 7,[90] 2023, Twitter's bird logo was replaced with
an image of the [Doge meme](/wiki/Doge_meme "Doge meme") for desktop users,
leading to a rise in Dogecoin prices.[91] No reason was given for the icon
change, with some speculating that it was a late [April Fool's
joke](/wiki/April_Fool%27s_joke "April Fool's joke"),[92] or an attempt to
[troll](/wiki/Trolling "Trolling") investors over the Dogecoin lawsuit that
Musk was seeking to end that week.

[93]
